definition: See under Violet.
Passing to the west.Toward heaven's descent had sloped his westering wheel. Milton.
Same as Tromp.
One of the holes in floor or other plates to permit water toflow through.
The European water ousel, or dipper.
See Wormil.
The green woodpecker, or yaffle. See Yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
A kind of knitting in which a number of threads areinterchained each with one or more contiguous threads on either side.
To reck; to care. [Obs.] Shak.
See Web, n., 8.
Abounding in qualities which cause weariness; wearisome.-- Wea"ri*ful*ly, adv.
In a wretched manner; miserably; despicable.
an arsenide of copper from Lake Superior.
The whortleberry, or bilberry.[He] looked ahead of him from behind a tump of whortles. R. D.Blackmore.
To tow or move, as a vessel, with a line, or warp, attached toa buoy, anchor, or other fixed object.
See Wadmol.
Of or pertaining to the lowest division of the Cretaceousformation in England and on the Continent, which overlies the Oöliticseries.

A very large lizard (Varanaus salvator) native of India. Itfrequents the borders of streams and swims actively. It becomes fiveor six feet long. Called also two-banded monitor, and kabaragoya. Thename is also applied to other aquatic monitors.
See Water soldier.
A depression in coal strata, hollowed out before the subsequentdeposition took place. [Eng.]
A kind of simple willow.
Any fish of the genus Cynoscion; a squeteague; -- so calledfrom its tender mouth. See Squeteague. Spotted weakfish (Zoöl.), thespotted squeteague.
A cone of paper which is placed in a vessel of lard or otherfat, and used as a taper. [Prov. Eng.]

a. & n. from Wreck, v. Wrecking car (Railway), a car fitted upwith apparatus and implements for removing the wreck occasioned by anaccident, as by a collision.-- Wrecking pump, a pump especially adapted for pumping water fromthe hull of a wrecked vessel.
A humming or whirring sound, like that of a body moving throughthe air with velocity; a whir.
The spotted flycatcher; -- so called from the white color ofthe under parts. [Prov. Eng.]
Any arthropod that breathes by means of gills.
A tool; an implement. [Scot.]
Same as Wiver.

Resembling wax in appearance or consistency; viscid; adhesive;soft; hence, yielding; pliable; impressible. "Waxy to persuasion."Bp. Hall. Waxy degeneration (Med.), amyloid degeneration. See underAmyloid.-- Waxy kidney, Waxy liver, etc. (Med.), a kidney or liver affectedby waxy degeneration.
Having the sails set in the manner called wing-and-wing.[Sailors' slang]
See Water brash, under Brash.
A meeting of wise men; the national council, or legislature, ofEngland in the days of the Anglo-Saxons, before the Norman Conquest.
The route taken by a party of Indians going on a warlikeexpedition. Schoolcraft. On the warpath, on a hostile expedition;hence, colloquially, about to attack a person or measure.
A narrow border, as of an ordinary, but not extending aroundthe ends. Welt joint, a joint, as of plates, made with a welt,instead of by overlapping the edges. See Weld, n., 1 (d).
Having or wearing no wig.
One who, or that which, waddles.
Same as Washerwoman, 2. [Prov. Eng.]
A fabulous deity supposed to dwell in, and preside over, somebody of water.
A turn of the cable about the end of the windlass, without thebits.
A coarse, hairy, woolen cloth, formerly used for garments bythe poor, and for various other purposes. [Spelled also wadmal,wadmeal, wadmoll, wadmel, etc.] Beck (Draper's Dict.). Sir W. Scott.

The theories and teachings in regard to heredity propounded bythe German biologist August Weismann, esp. in regard to germ plasm asthe basis of heredity and the impossibility of transmitting acquiredcharacteristics; -- often called neo-Darwinism.
Wariness; cautiousness. [Obs.] "Full of warefulness." Sir P.Sidney.
The lower, or bottom, pipe in a lift of pumps in a mine.Ansted.
Having a good intention.
To defend from the weather; to shelter. Shak.[We] barked the white spruce to weather-fend the roof. Emerson.

The class of ancient Hebrew writings which deal reflectivelywith general ethical and religious topics, as distinguished from theprophetic and liturgical literature, and from the law. It iscomprised chiefly in the books of Job, Proverbs, Ecclesiasticus,Ecclesiastes, and Wisdom of Solomon. The "wisdom" (Hokhmah) of thesewritings consists in detached sage utterances on concrete issues oflife, without the effort at philosophical system that appeared in thelater Hellenistic reflective writing beginning with Philo Judæus.

To give security for the performance of. Burrill. To wagebattle (O. Eng. Law), to give gage, or security, for joining in theduellum, or combat. See Wager of battel, under Wager, n. Burrill.-- To wage one's law (Law), to give security to make one's law. SeeWager of law, under Wager, n.
Quality or state of being waxy.

To reproach; to blame; to censure; also, to impute as blame.[Obs. or Scot.] Spenser.Though that I be jealous, wite me not. Chaucer.There if that I misspeak or say, Wite it the ale of Southwark, I youpray. Chaucer.
A tall, coarse dock growing in wet places. The American waterdock is Rumex orbiculatus, the European is R. Hydrolapathum.

To walk with short steps, swaying the body from one side to theother, like a duck or very fat person; to move clumsily andtotteringly along; to toddle; to stumble; as, a child waddles when hebegins to walk; a goose waddles. Shak.She drawls her words, and waddles in her pace. Young.
A kind of mint (Mentha aquatica) growing in wet places, andsometimes having a perfume resembling bergamot.
See Weasand. [Obs.]
A forest; -- used as a termination of names. See Weald.
One who wonders.
Having the taste or qualities of wine; vinous; as, grapes of awiny taste. Dampier.
See Whitsun. [Obs.]
That which serves to guard from falling water; a drip ordripstone.
A gossat, or rockling; -- called also whistler, three-beardedrockling, sea loach, and sorghe.
Infested by weevils; as, weeviled grain. [Written alsoweevilled.]
The redwing. [Prov. Eng.]

In general, any signal announcing information concerning winds,and esp. the expected approach of winds whose direction and force aredangerous to shipping, etc. The wind-signal system of the UnitedStates Weather Bureau consists of storm, information, hurricane, hotwind, and inland storm signals.
A small New Zealand owl (Sceloglaux albifacies). It has shortwings and long legs, and lives chiefly on the ground.
Abounding in capacity to warm; giving warmth; as, a warmfulgarment. [R.] Chapman.
To move quickly, but with great effort; to gallop. [Prov. Eng.& Scot.]

Bad, evil, or pernicious, in the highest degree, whether in aphysical or moral sense. See Worse. "Heard so oft in worst extremes."Milton.I have a wife, the worst that may be. Chaucer.If thou hadst not been born the worst of men, Thou hadst been a knaveand flatterer. Shak.
The anemone; -- so called because formerly supposed to openonly when the wind was blowing. See Anemone.
A person engaged in procuring or holding a woman or women forunwilling prostitution.
Using or doing customarily; accustomed; habituated; used. "Ashe was wont to go." Chaucer.If the ox were wont to push with his horn. Ex. xxi. 29.
A meadow, or piece of low, flat land, capable of being kept ina state of fertility by being overflowed with water from someadjoining river or stream.
Discovered, or first described, by Caspar Friedrich Wolff(1733-1794), the founder of modern embryology. Wolffian body, themesonephros.-- Wolffian duct, the duct from the Wolffian body.
One who draws metal into wire.
A whorl. See Whorl.

Any of numerous species of aquatic mites belonging to Hydrachnaand allied genera of the family Hydrachnidæ, usually having the legsfringed and adapted for swimming. They are often red or red and blackin color, and while young are parasites of fresh-water insects andmussels. Called also water tick, and water spider.
A south African proteaceous tree (Protea grandiflora); also,its tough wood, used for making wagon wheels.
See Veddahs.
Attentively; observingly. [Obs.] Shak.
The golden-eye.
The golden-eye. [Local, U.S.]
Meadow reed grass. See under Reed.
A thin, light fabric of wool. [Written also woollenet,woolenette, and woollenette.]
A wooden lining or boarding of the walls of apartments, usuallymade in panels.
Ripe for weeping; ready to weep. [Obs.] Shak.
Dwelling. See Wone. [Obs.]
The rapacious larva of a large water beetle (Hydrophiluspiceus), and of other similar species. See Illust. of Water beetle.
To feel or express undue care and anxiety; to manifestdisquietude or pain; to be fretful; to chafe; as, the child worries;the horse worries.
The quality or state of being winning. "Winningness in style."J. Morley.

Having or covering an angle wider than the ordinary; -- appliedto certain lenses of relatively short focus. Lenses for ordinarypurposes have an angle of 50º or less. Wide-angle lenses may cover asmuch as 100º and are useful for photographing at short range, but thepictures appear distorted.
A person who waltzes.
One who wrests.
A large West African chevrotain (Hyæmoschus aquaticus). It hasa larger body and shorter legs than the other allied species. Calledalso water deerlet.
Writhen.
A native or inhabitant of the west.
The wapiti, or wapiti, or American elk.
Same as Weir.
A pillow for the cheek; a pillow. [Obs. & R.]His bright helm was his wanger. Chaucer.
A thin, flying cloud; a rack.
A person appointed by law to take charge of goods, etc., thrownon shore after a shipwreck.
In a Whiggish manner.
To wither; to wilt. [R.]Weltered hearts and blighted . . . memories. I. Taylor.
Sorrowful; mournful. " Like wailful widows." Spenser. "Wailfulsonnets." Shak.
One who drinks wassail; one who engages in festivity,especially in drinking; a reveler.The rudeness and swilled insolence Of such late wassailers. Milton.
Wore.
At whatever time. "Whenever that shall be." Milton.
A thorny leguminous tree (Gleditschia monosperma) which growsin the swamps of the Mississippi valley.
One who moves or wears a halter; one likely to be hanged.[Colloq. & Obs.]I can tell you, I am a mad wag-halter. Marston.
A field. [Obs.] Spelman. "Woods and wonges." Havelok the Dane.
See Workyday.
One who wrongs or injures another. Shak. "Wrongers of theworld." Tennyson.
Capable of being wounded; vulnerable. [R.] Fuller.
Very large; whapping. [Colloq.]
See under Purslane.
See Wariangle. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Proof against penetration or permeation by water; impervious towater; as, a waterproof garment; a waterproof roof.
A bleacher of lines; a whitener; a whitster. [Prov. Eng.]
Incapable of being wearied.
See Waiver. [R.]
The tailrace of a mill. Knight.
Indulging in a vagrant or idle exercise of the imagination;roaming upon a fruitless quest; idly fanciful.
One who does well; one who does good to another; a benefactor.
p. p. of Wene. Chaucer.
See Water chevrotain.
Lamentation; loud weeping; wailing. [Obs.] Bp. Hacket.
A grass used for making ropes or for plaiting, esp. AgrostisSpica-ventis. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.] Shelley.

One of a system of tubular excretory organs having externalopenings, found in many invertebrates. They are believed to beanalogous in function to the kidneys of vertebrates. See Illust.under Trematodea, and Sporocyst.
To hoot. [Obs.]
In a welcome manner.
A vinelike plant (Vitis Caribæa) growing in parched districtsin the West Indies, and containing a great amount of sap which issometimes used for quenching thirst.

Structures in civil, military, or naval engineering, as docks,bridges, embankments, trenches, fortifications, and the like; also,the structures and grounds of a manufacturing establishment; as, ironworks; locomotive works; gas works. (d) pl.
See Wych-elm.
A sapling left standing in a fallen wood. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
Well. [Obs. or Scot.]
To frequent the company of wenches, or women of ill fame.
The whortleberry, or bilberry. See Whortleberry (a).
A piece of iron in a saddle near a horse's withers, tostrengthen the bow.
One who wishes well, or means kindly. [R.] "A well-willer ofyours." Brydges.
Any web-footed bird.
A castrated ram.
Becoming a workman, especially a skillful one; skillful; wellperformed.
The quality or state of being whole, entire, or sound;entireness; totality; completeness.
The honor or position of being a wrangler at the University ofCambridge, England.

Suitable to a woman, having the qualities of a woman;effeminate; not becoming a man; -- usually in a reproachful sense.See the Note under Effeminate. " Thy tears are womanish." Shak. "Womanish entreaties." Macaulay.A voice not soft, weak, piping, and womanish, but audible, strong,and manlike. Ascham.-- Wom"an*ish*ly, adv.-- Wom"an*ish*ness, n.
One who deals in words, or in mere words; a verbalist. [R.]"Some speculative wordsman." H. Bushnell.
Wise; knowing; skillful; sapient; erudite; prudent. Ex. xxviii.3.
A weaver. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having no wire; specif. (Elec.),
Ruinous; destructive. [Obs.]

A thorn, prickle, or sting with which many plants arefurnished. Concealed weapons. See under Concealed.-- Weapon salve, a salve which was supposed to cure a wound by beingapplied to the weapon that made it. [Obs.] Boyle.
One who, or that which, winnows; specifically, a winnowingmachine.
The European moor hen. [Prov. Eng.]
Any species of Vermetus.
Power or skill in flying. [R.] Duke of Argyll.
To bewilder; to perplex.Long lost and wildered in the maze of fate. Pope.Again the wildered fancy dreams Of spouting fountains, frozen as theyrose. Bryant.
Of or pertaining to Wallachia, a former principality, now partof the kingdom, of Roumania. -- n.

One of the neuter, or sterile, individuals of the social ants,bees, and white ants. The workers are generally females having thesexual organs imperfectly developed. See Ant, and White ant, underWhite.
Same as Curare.
Blameless. [Obs.] Spenser.
The common grayish or white variety of soapolite.
The soft and easily-worked wood of the tulip tree(Liriodendron). It is much used in cabinetwork, carriage building,etc.
See Leatherwood.
Originally, a large hound used in hunting wolves; now, any oneof certain breeds of large dogs, some of which are nearly identicalwith the great Danes.
To foretell the fate of; to predict; to destine to. [Scot.]Jamieson.
A dealer in the cakes called wafers; a confectioner. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Hydropathy.

Any one of several species of mice belonging to the genusHydromys, native of Australia and Tasmania. Their hind legs arestrong and their toes partially webbed. They live on the borders ofstreams, and swim well. They are remarkable as being the only rodentsfound in Australia.
Marsh pennywort. See under Marsh.
From what place soever; from what cause or source soever.Any idea, whencesoever we have it. Locke.
A method of teaching reading in which words are first taken assingle ideograms and later analyzed into their phonetic andalphabetic elements; -- contrasted with the alphabet and sentencemethods.
Weeds, collectively; also, a place full of weeds or for growingweeds. [R.] Dr. H. More.
Either of several tropical aquatic plants of the genusEichhornia, related to the pickerel weed.
See Welaway. [Obs.]
An American climbing shrub (Celastrus scandens). It bears aprofusion of yellow berrylike pods, which open in the autumn, anddisplay the scarlet coverings of the seeds.
That one of the two similar thermometers of a psychrometer thebulb of which is moistened; also, the entire instrument.
Cautiously; warily. [Obs.]They bound him hand and foot with iron chains, And with continualwatch did warely keep. Spenser.
An officer of the customs, whose duty it is to search vessels.[Eng.]
A disease of sheep; gid.
That part of the beard which grows upon the sides of the face,or upon the chin, or upon both; as, side whiskers; chin whiskers.
To be moved, or to pass, on a buoyant medium; to float.And now the shouts waft near the citadel. Dryden.
A westerner. [R.]
See Waive. [Obs.] Gower.

In a wonderful or surprising manner or degree; wonderfully.For sylphs, yet mindful of their ancient race, Are, as when women,wondrous fond of place. Pope.And now there came both mist and snow, And it grew wondrous cold.Coleridge.
To make like a woman; to make effeminate. [Obs.] V. Knox.
A kind of murrain affecting cattle. Crabb.
The ruddy duck. [Local, U. S.]
A windflower.
One who deals in wool.
The angler; -- called also widegab, and widegut.
With relation to this life; in a worldly manner.Subverting worldly strong and worldly wise By simply meek. Milton.
Having no weapon.
The European widgeon. [Prov. Eng.]
The Department of Foreign Affairs in the Chinese government.
Clay intersecting a vein. Weale.
In a warning manner.
A room in which goods are stored or exhibited for sale.
A house or shed in which wood is stored, and sheltered from theweather.
A fountain; a spring; a source of continual supply.Understanding is a wellspring of life unto him that hath it; but theinstruction of fools is folly. Prov. xvi. 22.
Having a distorted neck; having the deformity called wryneck.
An hydraulic ram.
The band of the sleeve of a shirt, or other garment, whichcovers the wrist.
A pack or bag of wool weighing two hundred and forty pounds.
The objective case of who. See Who.
Revengeful; angry; furious. [Obs.] -- Wreak"ful*ly, adv. [Obs.]
Abounding with willows; containing willows; covered orovergrown with willows. "Willowed meads." Collins.
A thorny European shrub (Hippophaë rhamnoides) resembling awillow.
Knew.
To howl. [Obs.] Wyclif.
An engraving on wood; also, a print from it. Same as Wood cut,under Wood.
The quality or state of wavering.
A drain or channel for draining off water.

To make a humming or hissing sound, like an arrow or ballflying through the air; to fly or move swiftly with a sharp hissingor whistling sound. [Written also whizz.]It flew, and whizzing, cut the liquid way. Dryden.
A waster; a thief. [Obs. or R.] [Written also wastour.]Chaucer. Southey.
Texture. [Obs.] Grew.
See under 1st Back.

A wood or forest; a wooded land or region; also, an opencountry; -- often used in place names.Fled all night long by glimmering waste and weald, And heard thespirits of the waste and weald Moan as she fled. Tennyson.Weald clay (Geol.), the uppermost member of the Wealden strata. SeeWealden.
Linsey-woolsey.
Impishness; magic.
imp. & p. p. of Work.Alas that I was wrought [created]! Chaucer.
To know; to learn. "I wot and wist alway." Chaucer.
A box for holding instruments or materials for work.
One who withstands, or opposes; an opponent; a resisting power.

Of or pertaining to Wales, or its inhabitants. [Sometimeswritten also Welch.] Welsh flannel, a fine kind of flannel made fromthe fleece of the flocks of the Welsh mountains, and largelymanufactured by hand.-- Welsh glaive, or Welsh hook, a weapon of war used in former timesby the Welsh, commonly regarded as a kind of poleax. Fairholt. Craig.-- Welsh mortgage (O. Eng. Law), a species of mortgage, being aconveyance of an estate, redeemable at any time on payment of theprincipal, with an understanding that the profits in the mean timeshall be received by the mortgagee without account, in satisfactionof interest. Burrill.-- Welsh mutton, a choice and delicate kind of mutton obtained froma breed of small sheep in Wales.-- Welsh onion (Bot.), a kind of onion (Allium fistulosum) havinghollow inflated stalks and leaves, but scarcely any bulb, a native ofSiberia. It is said to have been introduced from Germany, and issupposed to have derived its name from the German term wälschforeign.-- Welsh parsley, hemp, or halters made from hemp. [Obs. & Jocular]J. Fletcher.-- Welsh rabbit. See under Rabbit.
The act or process of whipstitching.
Having good breeding; refined in manners; polite; cultivated.I am as well-bred as the earl's granddaughter. Thackera
To court; to make love. Dryden.

a. & n. from Walk, v. Walking beam. See Beam, 10.-- Walking crane, a kind of traveling crane. See under Crane.-- Walking fern. (Bot.) See Walking leaf, below.-- Walking fish (Zoöl.), any one of numerous species of Asiaticfishes of the genus Ophiocephalus, some of which, as O. marulius,become over four feet long. They have a special cavity over the gillslined with a membrane adapted to retain moisture to aid inrespiration, and are thus able to travel considerable distances overthe land at night, whence the name. They construct a curious nest fortheir young. Called also langya.-- Walking gentleman (Theater), an actor who usually fillssubordinate parts which require a gentlemanly appearance but fewwords. [Cant] -- Walking lady (Theater), an actress who usually fillssuch parts as require only a ladylike appearance on the stage. [Cant]-- Walking leaf. (a) (Bot.) A little American fern (Camptosorusrhizophyllus); -- so called because the fronds taper into slenderprolongations which often root at the apex, thus producing newplants. (b) (Zoöl.) A leaf insect. See under Leaf.-- Walking papers, or Walking ticket, an order to leave; dismissal,as from office. [Colloq.] Bartlett.-- Walking stick. (a) A stick or staff carried in the hand for handfor support or amusement when walking; a cane. (b) (Zoöl.) A stickinsect; -- called also walking straw. See Illust. of Stick insect,under Stick.-- Walking wheel (Mach.), a prime mover consisting of a wheel drivenby the weight of men or animals walking either in it or on it; atreadwheel.
The panda.

The quality or state of being weary or tried; lassitude;exhaustion of strength; fatigue.With weariness and wine oppressed. Dryden.A man would die, though he were neither valiant nor miserable, onlyupon a weariness to do the same thing so oft over and over. Bacon.
See Weanel. [Obs.] Tusser.
A compact woodlike variety of asbestus.
One who cavils at words.
The visible regions of the air; the vault of heaven; the sky.On the welkne shoon the sterres lyght. Chaucer.The fair welkin foully overcast. Spenser.When storms the welkin rend. Wordsworth.
A large North American snipe (Symphemia semipalmata); -- calledalso pill-willet, will-willet, semipalmated tattler, or snipe, ducksnipe, and stone curlew. Carolina willet, the Hudsonian godwit.
A sudden illness or relapse, often attended with fever, whichattacks women in childbed. [Scot.]
A potter's wheel.

Any one of numerous species of butterflies belonging to Pieris,and allied genera in which the color is usually white. See Cabbagebutterfly, under Cabbage. Black and white. See under Black.-- Flake white, Paris white, etc. See under Flack, Paris, etc.-- White of a seed (Bot.), the albumen. See Albumen, 2.-- White of egg, the viscous pellucid fluid which surrounds the yolkin an egg, particularly in the egg of a fowl. In a hen's egg it isalkaline, and contains about 86 per cent of water and 14 per cent ofsolid matter, the greater portion of which is egg albumin. Itlikewise contains a small amount of globulin, and traces of fats andsugar, with some inorganic matter. Heated above 60º C. it coagulatesto a solid mass, owing to the albumin which it contains. Parr.-- White of the eye (Anat.), the white part of the ball of the eyesurrounding the transparent cornea.

Any one of several plants, as Artemisia santonica, andChenopodium anthelminticum, whose seeds have the property ofexpelling worms from the stomach and intestines. Wormseed mustard, aslender, cruciferous plant (Erysinum cheiranthoides) having smalllanceolate leaves.
From which; from which or what place. Tennyson.

The quality or state of being worthy; desert; merit;excellence; dignity; virtue; worth.Who is sure he hath a soul, unless It see, and judge, and followworthiness Donne.She is not worthy to be loved that hath not some feeling of her ownworthiness. Sir P. Sidney.The prayers which our Savior made were for his own worthinessaccepted. Hooker.
See Wishtonwish.
Michigan; -- a nickname.
A kind of speedwell (Veronica hederifolia) which spreadschiefly in winter. Dr. Prior.
The quality or state of being washy, watery, or weak.
A white mark in the forehead of a horse, descending almost tothe nose; -- called also white-blaze.
See Weasand. [Obs.]
The windpipe; -- called also, formerly, wesil. [Formerly,written also, wesand, and wezand.]Cut his weasand with thy knife. Shak.
Faring well; prosperous; thriving. [Obs.] "A welfaring person."Chaucer.
Capable or worthy of being wished for; desirable. Udall.
A curly-haired breed of spaniels, naturally very fond of thewater.

To lie in wait for; to meet or encounter in the way;especially, to watch for the passing of, with a view to seize, rob,or slay; to beset in ambush.Falstaff, Bardolph, Peto, and Gadshill shall rob those men that wehave already waylaid. Shak.She often contrived to waylay him in his walks. Sir W. Scott.
See Weasand. [Obs.]

To lie in folds; also, to appear as if laid in folds or plaits;to ripple; to undulate. "Wimpling waves." Longfellow.For with a veil, that wimpled everywhere, Her head and face was hid.Spenser.With me through . . . meadows stray, Where wimpling waters make theirway. Ramsay.

An instrument to indicate the state of the atmosphere,especially changes of atmospheric pressure, and hence changes ofweather, as a barometer or baroscope. Poor man's weatherglass. (Bot.)See under Poor.
See Whidan bird.
Chips made by one who whittles; shavings cut from a stick witha knife.
1st & 3d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know. See the Note underWit, v. [Obs.]Brethren, I wot that through ignorance ye did it. Acts iii. 17.

Any one of numerous species of kangaroos belonging to the genusHalmaturus, native of Australia and Tasmania, especially the smallerspecies, as the brush kangaroo (H. Bennettii) and the pademelon (H.thetidis). The wallabies chiefly inhabit the wooded district andbushy plains. [Written also wallabee, and whallabee.]
Full of wiles; trickish; deceitful.
A water hole in the bed of an intermittent stream, esp. thebowl at the foot of a cliff over which the stream leaps when in theflood stage. [Western U. S.]
A leather thong. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U. S.]
A petty or inferior Whig; -- used in contempt. Spectator.
A woven band of cotton or flax, used for reins, girths, bedbottoms, etc.
Wicked. [Obs.] Piers Plowman. "With full wikke intent."Chaucer.
See Wry. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A kind of plant with acrid leaves. See under 2d Plantain.
To roll; esp., to roll in anything defiling or unclean. "Wallowthyself in ashes." Jer. vi. 26.
A contract by which two parties or more agree that a certainsum of money, or other thing, shall be paid or delivered to one ofthem, on the happening or not happening of an uncertain event.Bouvier.
The grivet.
Made of, secured by, or covered with, wickers or wickerwork.Ships of light timber, wickered with osier between, and covered overwith leather. Milton.
Fit to be walked on; capable of being walked on or over. [R.]Swift.
A variety of chicken pox, or varicella. Dunglison.
Having the feet, or the shoes on the feet, wet.
One who, or that which, whirls.
The act of withdrawing; withdrawal. W. Belsham.
A low, narrowleaved evergreen shrub (Cneorum tricoccon) foundin Southern Europe.

Taking one's own way; disobedient; froward; perverse; willful.My wife is in a wayward mood. Shak.Wayward beauty doth not fancy move. Fairfax.Wilt thou forgive the wayward thought Keble.-- Way"ward*ly, adv.-- Way"ward*ness, n.
A small East Indian wild cat (Felis wagati), regarded by someas a variety of the leopard cat.
To journey; to travel; to go to and fro. [Obs.]A certain Laconian, as he wayfared, came unto a place where theredwelt an old friend of his. Holland.
Having a thin, sharp face, like a weasel.
To fallow or till in winter. [Prov. Eng.]
Almost; nearly. Chaucer.
When. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Way; road; path. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who affects repartee; a wit-cracker. [Obs.] Shak.
imp. of Weld, to wield. Chaucer.
Free from weeds or noxious matter.
Wet. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any one of numerous species of small marine bivalves belongingto Donax and allied genera in which the shell is wedge-shaped.
p. p. of Wreak. Chaucer.
To bend or strain out of its position; as, to wring a mast.
A kind of froth seen on herbs. [Obs.]
The quality or state of being wry, or distorted. W. Montagu.

A sect of dissenters from the ecclesiastical system of theRoman Catholic Church, who in the 13th century were driven bypersecution to the valleys of Piedmont, where the sect survives. Theyprofess substantially Protestant principles.
A form of degeneration occurring in nerve fibers as a result oftheir division; -- so called from Dr. Waller, who published anaccount of it in 1850.
Any one of three species of Australian burrowing marsupials ofthe genus Phascolomys, especially the common species (P. ursinus).They are nocturnal in their habits, and feed mostly on roots.
Suitable to winter; resembling winter, or what belongs towinter; brumal; hyemal; cold; stormy; wintery.Touch our chilled hearts with vernal smile, Our wintry course do thoubeguile. Keble.
A day on which work is performed, as distinguished from Sunday,festivals, etc., a working day.
Having no wem, or blemish; spotless. [Obs.] "Virgin wemless."Chaucer.
A broad, thin plank, fixed along the gunwale of boat to keepthe sea from breaking inboard; also, a plank on the sill of a lowerdeck port, for the same purpose; -- called also wasteboard. Mar. Di
Whatever. "In whatsoever shape he lurk." Milton.Whatsoever God hath said unto thee, do. Gen. xxxi. 16.
To wish; to desire. [Obs.] "He willneth no destruction."Chaucer.
A man who has lost his wife by death, and has not marriedagain. Shak.
The difference between the diameter of the bore of a gun andthat of the shot fired from it.
Barren of wit; destitute of genius. Examiner.
A genus of climbing leguminous plants bearing long, pendulousclusters of pale bluish flowers.

A little red flower, no doubt the pimpernel, which, when itopens in the morning, is supposed to bode a fair day. See Pimpernel.There is small red flower in the stubble fields, which country peoplecall the wincopipe; which if it opens in the morning, you may be surea fair day will follow. Bacon.
See Soluble glass, under Glass.

A piece of stone, natural or artificial, used for whetting, orsharpening, edge tools.The dullness of the fools is the whetstone of the wits. Shak.Diligence is to the understanding as the whetstone to the razor.South.

Land covered with wood or trees; forest; land on which treesare suffered to grow, either for fuel or timber.Here hills and vales, the woodland and the plain, Here earth andwater seem to strive again. Pope.Woodlands and cultivated fields are harmoniously blended. Bancroft.
In a weeping manner.
To marry; to unite in marriage; to wed. [R.] "Man thuswedlocked." Milton.
To kill by the cold, or exposure to the inclemency of winter;as, the wheat was winterkilled. [U. S.]
A woman held in involuntary confinement for purposes ofprostitution; loosely, any woman forced into unwilling prostitution.
To arrange in lines or windrows, as hay when newly made. Forby.
See Water line, 2. [R.]
The treatment of wounds or ulcers by the application of water;also, a dressing saturated with water only, for application to awound or an ulcer.
A young oak, or other timber plant, laid down in a hedge amongthe whitethorn or other plants used in hedges.
To show; to teach; to inform; to guide; to direct. [Obs.]Ere we depart I shall thee so well wisse That of mine house ne shaltthou never misse. Chaucer.
Same as Weir.
A walrus. [Obs.] Woodward.
Trouble; anxiety; worry. [Colloq. U. S.]

An Indian cabin or hut, usually of a conical form, and made ofa framework of poles covered with hides, bark, or mats; -- calledalso tepee. [Sometimes written also weekwam.]Very spacious was the wigwam, Made of deerskin dressed and whitened,With the gods of the Dacotahs Drawn and painted on its curtains.Longfellow.
Wool. [Obs.] Chaucer.
See Whelk. [Obs.]
The act of one who, or that which, winnows.

A wild or uncultivated plant; especially, a wild apple tree orcrab apple; also, the fruit of such a plant. Spenser.Ten ruddy wildings in the wood I found. Dryden.The fruit of the tree . . . is small, of little juice, and badquality. I presume it to be a wilding. Landor.
See Swarf.
A whitener; a bleacher; a whitester. [Obs.]The whitsters in Datchet mead. Shak.
Beaten or harassed by the weather; worn by exposure to theweather, especially to severe weather. Shak.
A statesman; a politician. [R.] Shak.
One whose intention is good. "Well-meaners think no harm."Dryden.

Having the power of breathing impaired by the rupture,dilatation, or running together of air cells of the lungs, so thatwhile the inspiration is by one effort, the expiration is by two;affected with pulmonary emphysema or with heaves; -- said of a horse.Youatt.

Causing weariness; tiresome; tedious; weariful; as, a wearisomemarch; a wearisome day's work; a wearisome book.These high wild hills and rough uneven ways Draws out our miles, andmakes them wearisome. Shak.
Flat; insipid. [Obs.] Overbury.
Any species of Tardigrada, 2. See Illust. of Tardigrada.
A skin with the wool; a skin from which the wool has not beensheared or pulled. [Written also woolfel.]
Wonderfully; wondrously. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Bad, ill, evil, or corrupt, in a greater degree; more bad orevil; less good; specifically, in poorer health; more sick; -- usedboth in a physical and moral sense.Or worse, if men worse can devise. Chaucer.[She] was nothing bettered, but rather grew worse. Mark v. 26.Evil men and seducers shall wax worse and worse. 2 Tim. iii. 13.There are men who seem to believe they are not bad while another canbe found worse. Rambler."But I love him." "Love him Worse and worse." Gay.
A little while ago; recently; just now; erewhile. [Obs.]Helpeth me now as I did you whilere. Chaucer.He who, with all heaven's heraldry, whilere Entered the world.Milton.
One who pretends to be wise; a wiseacre; a witling. Donne.
Having the appearance of that which is seen in pictures byAntoine Watteau, a French painter of the eighteenth century; --saidesp. of women's garments; as, a Watteau bodice.
pl. of Wolf.
The quality or state of being woody. Evelyn.
A plant which keeps its leaves green through the winter.
See Wormil.
To separate chaff from grain.Winnow not with every wind. Ecclus. v. 9.
Pale or light blue. [Obs.] "Watchet mantles." Spenser.Who stares in Germany at watchet eyes Dryden.
A perforated steel die through which wires or tubes are drawnto form them.

The figure inclosed by lines through the points contact of thewheels of a vehicle, etc., with the surface or rails on which theyrun; more esp., the length of this figure between the points ofcontact of the two extreme wheels on either side.
Calcium oxalate, occurring in colorless or white monocliniccrystals.
Not to be wielded; unmanageable; unwieldy. [R.] "Wieldlessmight." Spenser.
A fulling mill. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
2d pers. sing. pres. of Wit, to know. [Obs.] Spenser.
imp. of Wear.
While. [Archaic]Whilst the emperor lay at Antioch. Gibbon.The whilst, in the meantime; while. [Archaic.] Shak.
A dweller in a woodland.
Having a roof, or top, shaped like an inverted U; wagon-headed.
A sea view; -- distinguished from landscape. [Jocose] Fairholt.
Something requiring much care and expense and yielding littleprofit; any burdensome possession. [Slang]
One who witness.
p. p. of Weave. Woven paper, or Wove paper, writing paperhaving an even, uniform surface, without watermarks.

Of or pertaining to Auer von Welsbach or the incandescent gasburner invented by him. -- Welsbach burner, a burner in which thecombustion of a mixture of air and gas or vapor is employed to heatto incandescence a mantle composed of thoria and ceria. The mantle ismade by soaking a "stocking" in a solution of nitrates of thorium andcerium (approx. 99 : 1), drying, and, for use, igniting to burn thethread and convert the nitrates into oxides, which remain as afragile ash. The light far exceeds that obtained from the same amountof gas with the ordinary fishtail burner, but has a slight greenishhue.
To work. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Any bird that frequents the water, or lives about rivers,lakes, etc., or on or near the sea; an aquatic fowl; -- used alsocollectively.
Leucorrh
Representing the whole figure; -- said of a picture or statue.-- n.
A rope or halter made of flexible twigs, or withes, as ofbirch. [Scot.]
The common beam tree of England (Pyrus Aria); -- so called fromthe white, woolly under surface of the leaves.

a. & n. from Whoop, v. t. Whooping cough (Med.), a violent,convulsive cough, returning at longer or shorter intervals, andconsisting of several expirations, followed by a sonorousinspiration, or whoop; chin cough; hooping cough. Dunglison.-- Whooping crane (Zoöl.), a North American crane (Crus Americana)noted for the loud, whooplike note which it utters.-- Whooping swan (Zoöl.), the whooper swan. See the Note under Swan.
To furnish. [Obs.] "To warnstore your house." Chaucer.

Lit., world view; a conception of the course of events in, andof the purpose of, the world as a whole, forming a philosophical viewor apprehension of the universe; the general idea embodied in acosmology.
Having a pale look; feeble; hence, cowardly; pusillanimous;dastardly.They must not be milksops, nor white-livered knights. Latimer.
To set against; to oppose. [Obs.] "Their way he them withset."R. of Brunne.
Whether. [Obs.]
A marine shell of the genus Turbo. See Turbo.

To subject, as cloth or yarn, to the fulling process; to full.[Obs. or Scot.] To walk the plank, to walk off the plank into thewater and be drowned; -- an expression derived from the practice ofpirates who extended a plank from the side of a ship, and compelledthose whom they would drown to walk off into the water; figuratively,to vacate an office by compulsion. Bartlett.
A winkle. [Local, U.S.]

Filled or saturated with water so as to be heavy, unmanageable,or loglike; -- said of a vessel, when, by receiving a great quantityof water into her hold, she has become so heavy as not to bemanageable by the helm.
Wreak. [Obs.] Chaucer.

a. & n. from Wait, v. In waiting, in attendance; as, lords inwaiting. [Eng.] -- Waiting gentlewoman, a woman who waits upon aperson of rank.-- Waiting maid, Waiting woman, a maid or woman who waits uponanother as a personal servant.
The capuchin. See Capuchin, 3 (a).
Weapons, collectively; as, an array of weaponry. [Poetic]
The snow goose. [Canadian, & Local U. S.]
Made wan, or pale.
A circle of two or more leaves, flowers, or other organs, aboutthe same part or joint of a stem.
Becoming or like a widow.
Any weak, thin drink.
A woodpecker.
To cry, as a cat; to waul. [Obs.] Spenser.
A screw propeller.
A doing well; right performance of duties. Also usedadjectively.
To wane. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having windows or openings. [R.] "Looped and windowedraggedness." Shak.
The carp; -- so called on account of its cunning. Walton.
Yelping. [R.] Fuller.
The paxwax. See Paxwax.
Conveyance on a buoyant medium, as air or water. Shak.Boats prepared for waftage to and fro. Drayton.
A voltaic battery in which the exciting fluid is water.
A withered person; one who is decrepit. [Obs.] Chapman.
A waif. [Obs.] Spenser.
Be silent; be still; hush; silence.
The side of the way; the edge or border of a road or path.
The buffel duck.
Any plant of the aquatic umbelliferous genus Sium, poisonousherbs with pinnate or dissected leaves and small white flowers.
A genus of brachiopods of which many species are found in thefossil state. A few still exist in the deep sea.
A white mark on the foot of a horse, between the fetlock andthe coffin.
A bag for holding implements or materials for work; especially,a reticule, or bag for holding needlework, and the like.
The pied wagtail; -- so called because it frequents ponds.
In a woundy manner; excessively; woundy. [Obs.]
A barometer in which the changes of atmospheric pressure areindicated by the motion of a column of water instead of mercury. Itrequires a column of water about thirty-three feet in height.
A supply of water; specifically, water collected, as inreservoirs, and conveyed, as by pipes, for use in a city, mill, orthe like.
To wrinkle. [Obs.] Shak.
The common sandpiper.
A gavel or rent paid for a privilege, as of fishing, in someriver or water.
In a winding manner.
An herbaceous cruciferous plant (Isatis tinctoria). It wasformerly cultivated for the blue coloring matter derived from itsleaves.
Of a color between white and brown. Pegge.
A perennial composite herb (Chrysanthemum Leucanthemum) withconspicuous white rays and a yellow disk, a common weed in grasslands and pastures; -- called also oxeye daisy.
Any plant of the natural order Elatineæ, consisting of twogenera (Elatine, and Bergia), mostly small annual herbs growing inthe edges of ponds. Some have a peppery or acrid taste.
A storm characterized by high wind with little or no rain.
A little; a bit, as of space, time, or distance. [Obs. orScot.]
Woeful. [Obs.] Langhorne.
The land-locked variety of the common salmon. [Canada]
Weight. [Obs.]

Destitute of wit or understanding; wanting thought; hence,indiscreet; not under the guidance of judgment. "Witless bravery."Shak.A witty mother! witless else her son. Shak.Witless pity breedeth fruitless love. Fairfax.-- Wit"less*ly, adv.-- Wit"less*ness, n.
The skin of a newborn seal; also, the seal itself. [Sealers'Cant]
Without; outside' outwardly. Cf. Withinforth. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Penetrated by worms; injured by worms; worm-eaten; as, wormedtimber.
Full of wrong; injurious; unjust; unfair; as, a wrongful takingof property; wrongful dealing.-- Wrong"ful*ly, adv.-- Wrong"ful*ness, n.
Like a wittol; cuckoldly. [Obs.] Shak.
The lapwing; the wipe; -- so called from its cry.
A deep blue variety of iolite, sometimes used as a gem; --called also saphir d'eau.
Same as Wariangle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Shaped like the lash of a whip; long, slender, round, andtapering; as, a whip-shaped root or stem.
Having a weak mind, either naturally or by reason of disease;feebleminded; foolish; idiotic.-- Weak"-mind`ed*ness, n.
Wake.
See Waywode.

A person whose soul is set upon gaining temporal possessions;one devoted to this world and its enjoyments.A foutre for the world and worldlings base. Shak.If we consider the expectations of futurity, the worldling gives upthe argument. Rogers.And worldlings blot the temple's gold. Keble.
A cereal grass (Triticum vulgare) and its grain, whichfurnishes a white flour for bread, and, next to rice, is the grainmost largely used by the human race.

A composite plant (Artemisia Absinthium), having a bitter andslightly aromatic taste, formerly used as a tonic and a vermifuge,and to protect woolen garments from moths. It gives the peculiarflavor to the cordial called absinthe. The volatile oil is a narcoticpoison. The term is often extended to other species of the samegenus.
Same as Wale, n., 4.
Any room or apartment used especially for labor.
See Woe. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To lead a military life; to carry on continual wars. Camden.

Going away; departing; of or pertaining to one who goes away.Way-going crop (Law of Leases), a crop of grain to which tenants foryears are sometimes entitled by custom; grain sown in the fall to bereaped at the next harvest; a crop which will not ripen until afterthe termination of the lease. Burrill.
A solution in water of a gaseous or readily volatile substance;as, ammonia water. U. S. Pharm.
Unless; except; -- introducing a clause.You will never live to my age without you keep yourselves in breathwith exercise, and in heart with joyfulness. Sir P. Sidney.
In what place soever; in whatever place; wherever.
Quality or state of being weasy; full feeding; sensualindulgence. [Obs.] Joye.
Same as Quicken tree.
See Warye. [Obs.]
A little whiff or puff.
The water cress. (3)
The retention of the afterbirth in cows. Gardner.
A weak or feeble creature. Shak. "All looking on him as aweakling, which would post to the grave." Fuller.We may not be weaklings because we have a strong enemy. Latimer.
One often quarreled with; -- darling. [Obs.]Better be an old man's darling than a young man's warling. Camde
See Waddy.
Workmanship. [R.]
To cause to pass away pleasantly or without irksomeness ordisgust; to spend or pass; -- usually followed by away.The lovely lady whiled the hours away. Longfellow.

To wither; to fade; also, to decay; to decline; to wane. [Obs.]When ruddy Phwelk in west. Spenser.The church, that before by insensible degrees welked and impaired,now with large steps went down hill decaying. Milton.
Ware; aware. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A goose-neck apparatus for supplying water from an elevatedtank, as to the tender of a locomotive.
Having no road or path; pathless.
One who watches; one who sits up or continues; a diligentobserver; specifically, one who attends upon the sick during thenight.

A second or reciprocal distress of other goods in lieu of goodswhich were taken by a first distress and have been eloigned; a takingby way of reprisal; -- chiefly used in the expression capias inwithernam, which is the name of a writ used in connection with theaction of replevin (sometimes called a writ of reprisal), whichissues to a defendant in replevin when he has obtained judgment for areturn of the chattels replevied, and fails to obtain them on thewrit of return. Blackstone.
The constellation Charles's Wain, or Ursa Major. See Ursamajor, under Ursa.
The quality or state of being weighty; weight; force;importance; impressiveness.
Excessive use of the pronoun we; -- called also weism. [Colloq.or Cant]
Inclined to worry or fret; also, causing worry or annoyance.
2d pers. sing. of Will.
The American elk (Cervus Canadensis). It is closely related tothe European red deer, which it somewhat exceeds in size.
Wreathed; twisted; curled; spiral; also, full of wreaths."Wreathy spires, and cochleary turnings about." Sir T. Browne.
A leguminous plant (Genista tinctoria) of Europe and RussianAsia, and adventitious in America; -- called also greenwood,greenweed, dyer's greenweed, and whin, wood-wash, wood-wax, and wood-waxen.
Injured or hurt in the withers, as a horse.
The quality or state of being whimsical; freakishness;whimsical disposition.

The manner or action of a wag; mischievous merriment; sportivetrick or gayety; good-humored sarcasm; pleasantry; jocularity; as,the waggery of a schoolboy. Locke.A drollery and lurking waggery of expression. W. Irving.
A jar or bottle, as of porous earthenware, in which water iscooled by evaporation.
In a whining manner; in a tone of mean complaint.
Of or pertaining to a widow; vidual. [Obs.] Bale.
Appearing as if overlaid with a thin layer of different color;-- said of the colors of certain birds and insects.
See Wabble.
See Washboard, 3.
A form of rifled cannon and small arms invented by Sir JosephWhitworth, of Manchester, England.
In a wary manner.

Destitute of worth; having no value, virtue, excellence,dignity, or the like; undeserving; valueless; useless; vile; mean;as, a worthless garment; a worthless ship; a worthless man or woman;a worthless magistrate.'T is a worthless world to win or lose. Byron.-- Worth"less*ly, adv.-- Worth"less*ness, n.
A bastard wing, or alula.
A kind of bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis).He bare a burden ybound with a broad list, In a withewyndes wiseybounden about. Piers Plowman.
Any signal giving information about the weather. The systemused by the United States Weather Bureau includes temperature, coldor hot wave, rain or snow, wind direction, storm, and hurricanesignals.
A person of a perverse understanding or obstinate character.[R.]
A fife or small flute. [Obs.] Douce.

A small nematode worm (Anguillula tritici) which attacks thegrains of wheat in the ear. It is found in wheat affected with smut,each of the diseased grains containing a large number of the minuteyoung of the worm.
In the inner parts; inside. [Obs.] Graves.

a. & n. from Weed, v. Weeding chisel, a tool with a dividedchisel-like end, for cutting the roots of large weeds under ground.-- Weeding forceps, an instrument for taking up some sorts of plantsin weeding.-- Weeding fork, a strong, three-pronged fork, used in clearingground of weeds; -- called also weeding iron.-- Weeding hook. Same as Weed hook, under 3d Weed.-- Weeding iron. See Weeding fork, above.-- Weeding tongs. Same as Weeding forceps, above.
In a wooing manner; enticingly; with persuasiveness. Shak.
Moderately wide. Tyndall.
A sea robin having large, winglike pectoral fins. See Searobin, under Robin.
See Wormil.

In a worthy manner; excellently; deservedly; according tomerit; justly; suitably; becomingly.You worthily succeed not only to the honors of your ancestors, butalso to their virtues. Dryden.Some may very worthily deserve to be hated. South.
Having weak knees; hence, easily yielding; wanting resolution.H. James.
An aquatic plant (Schollera graminea) with grassy leaves, andyellow star-shaped blossoms.
p. p. of Wash. Chaucer.
A wearing of woolen clothes next the skin as a matter ofpenance. [Obs.]Their . . . woolward-going, and rising at midnight. Tyndale.
The shutter, casement, sash with its fittings, or otherframework, which closes a window opening.
See Weld.
The quality or state of being welcome; gratefulness;agreeableness; kind reception.
Indian rice. See under Rice.
Having pinnate or pinnately divided leaves.
prevented from sailing, by a contrary wind. See Weatherbound.
Fully awake; not Dickens.
A name given to the first power spinning machine, becausedriven by water power.
At what time soever; at whatever time; whenever. Mark xiv. 7.
A prejectile used in the Whitworth gun.

The end of the week; specif., though loosely, the periodobserved commonly as a holiday, from Saturday noon or Friday night toMonday; as, to visit one for a week-end; also, a house party during aweek-end.
The distance, reckoned toward the west, between the twomeridians passing through the extremities of a course, or portion ofa ship's path; the departure of a course which lies to the west ofnorth.
See Welaway. [Obs.]
In racing, the going over a course by a horse which has nocompetitor for the prize; hence, colloquially, a one-sided contest;an uncontested, or an easy, victory.
The sheatfish; -- called also waller.
The Dipper, or Charles's Wain.

Devoted to worldly interests; mindful of the affairs of thepresent life, and forgetful of those of the future; loving andpursuing this world's goods, to the exclusion of piety and attentionto spiritual concerns.-- World"ly*mind`ed*ness, n.
The American lotus, and its edible seeds, which somewhatresemble chinquapins. Cf. Yoncopin.
A somewhat heart-shaped cherry with a whitish skin.
A wave. [Obs.] Spenser.
A disease in the feet of a horse or other beast.
See 2d Will. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Of, pertaining to, or observed at, Whitsuntide; as, Whitsunweek; Whitsun Tuesday; Whitsun pastorals.
Formerly; once; of old; erewhile; at times. [Obs. or Poetic]Spenser.Whilom, as olde stories tellen us, There was a duke that highteTheseus. Chaucer.
See Welshman. [R.]
Alas! Welaway! Shak.
Being without warmth; not communicating warmth; cold. [R.]Coleridge.
The dwarf elder, or danewort (Sambucus Ebulus).
Possessed of wit; witty. [R.] R. North.
The quality of being wide; extent from side to side; breadth;wideness; as, the width of cloth; the width of a door.
Whereas.And flight and die is death destroying death; Where fearing dyingpays death servile breath. Shak.

The seventh Sunday, and the fiftieth day, after Easter; afestival of the church in commemoration of the descent of the HolySpirit on the day of Pentecost; Pentecost; -- so called, it is said,because, in the primitive church, those who had been newly baptizedappeared at church between Easter and Pentecost in white garments.
Pertaining to, or designed for, wear; as, wearing apparel.
The mark of a stripe. See Wale.
Like a wedge; wedge-shaped.

The very large ovoid or roundish fruit of a cucurbitaceousplant (Citrullus vulgaris) of many varieties; also, the plant itself.The fruit sometimes weighs many pounds; its pulp is usually pink incolor, and full of a sweet watery juice. It is a native of tropicalAfrica, but is now cultivated in many countries. See Illust. ofMelon.
See under Vole.
Any one of numerous species of stinging hymenopterous insects,esp. any of the numerous species of the genus Vespa, which includesthe true, or social, wasps, some of which are called yellow jackets.
imp. of Wax. Gower.
The quality or state of being wan; a sallow, dead, pale color;paleness; pallor; as, the wanness of the cheeks after a fever.
The language of the Wends.
See Waivure. [R.]
One who paints in water colors.
A form of vessel, often with steam power, having sharp ends anda very convex upper deck, much used on the Great Lakes, esp. forcarrying grain.
Adapted to excite wonder or admiration; surprising; strange;astonishing.
Worn, smoothed, or polished by the action of water; as,waterworn stones.

Way of being or acting; manner; mode; fashion. "All armed incomplete wise." Spenser.To love her in my beste wyse. Chaucer.This song she sings in most commanding wise. Sir P. Sidney.Let not these blessings then, sent from above, Abused be, or spilt inprofane wise. Fairfax.
The English bilberry; -- so called because it grows on moorsamong the whins, or furze. Dr. Prior.
One who whitewashes.
See Wether. Sir W. Scott.
In a wood, mad, or raving manner; madly; furiously. [Obs.]Chaucer.
Capable of being worn; suitable to be worn.
A kind of implement used for tearing up weeds esp. on summerfallows. [Prov. Eng.]
Producing prosperity or happiness; blessed. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Certainly. [Obs.] "God so wisly have mercy on me." Chaucer.

A map or chart showing the principal meteorological elements ata given hour and over an extended region. Such maps usually show theheight of the barometer, the temperature of the air, the relativehumidity, the state of the weather, and the direction and velocity ofthe wind. Isobars and isotherms outline the general distribution oftemperature and pressure, while shaded areas indicate the sectionsover which rain has just fallen. Other lines inclose areas where thetemperature has fallen or risen markedly. In tabular form are shownchanges of pressure and of temperature, maximum and minimumtemperatures, and total rain for each weather station since the lastissue, usually 12 hours.
See Wapatoo.

A man engaged or experienced in war, or in the military life; asoldier; a champion.Warriors old with ordered spear and shield. Milton.Warrior ant (Zoöl.), a reddish ant (Formica sanguinea) native ofEurope and America. It is one of the species which move in armies tocapture and enslave other ants.
A period of seven days, usually that reckoned from one Sabbathor Sunday to the next.I fast twice in the week. Luke xviii. 12.

Beads made of shells, used by the North American Indians asmoney, and also wrought into belts, etc., as an ornament.Round his waist his belt of wampum. Longfellow.Girded with his wampum braid. Whittier.
An Australian tree (Pittosporum bicolor); also, its wood, usedin making waddies.
Of extensive reading; deeply versed; -- often followed by in.
An aroid herb (Calla palustris) having a white spathe. It is aninhabitant of the north temperate zone.
To woo. [Obs.] Chaucer.

In some northern counties of England, a division, or district,answering to the hundred in other counties. Yorkshire, Lincolnshire,and Nottinghamshire are divided into wapentakes, instead of hundreds.[Written also wapentac.] Selden. Blackstone.
The forked bone in front of the breastbone in birds; -- calledalso merrythought, and wishing bone. See Merrythought, and Furculum.
That witches or enchants; suited to enchantment or witchcraft;bewitching. "The very witching time of night." Shak.-- Witch"ing*ly, adv.
The buck bean.
One who makes a way; a precursor. [R.] Bacon.

Authorized by commission, precept, or right; justifiable;defensible; as, the seizure of a thief is always warrantable by lawand justice; falsehood is never warrantable.His meals are coarse and short, his employment warrantable, his sleepcertain and refreshing. South.-- War"rant*a*ble*ness, n.-- War"rant*bly, adv.
One who warns; an admonisher.
To beat; to whap. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Sir T. Malory.
A firework which, while burning, is caused to revolve on anaxis by the reaction of the escaping gases.(f) (Poetry) The burden or refrain of a song.
A weanling. [Obs.] Spenser.
The duty of keeping watch and ward (see the Note under Watch,n., 1) with a horn to be blown upon any occasion of surprise.Burrill.
A plant (Pistia stratiotes) which floats on tropical waters,and forms a rosette of spongy, wedge-shaped leaves. J. Smith (Dict.Econ. Plants).
a & n. from Whip, v. Whipping post, a post to which offendersare tied, to be legally whipped.
A kind of carpet woven with loops like the Brussels, butdiffering from it in having the loops cut so as to form an elasticvelvet pile; -- so called because made originally at Wilton, England.
One engaged in warfare; a military man; a soldier; a warrior.

To stand against; to oppose; to resist, either with physical ormoral force; as, to withstand an attack of troops; to withstandeloquence or arguments. Piers Plowman.I withstood him to the face. Gal. ii. 11.Some village Hampden, that, with dauntless breast. The little tyrantof his fields withstood. Gray.
Surrounded with happiness or prosperity. [Obs.]Fair and rich and young and wel-begone. Chaucer.

A street towards the southern end of the borough of Manhattan,New York City, extending from Broadway to the East River; -- socalled from the old wall which extended along it when the citybelonged to the Dutch. It is the chief financial center of the UnitedStates, hence the name is often used for the money market and thefinancial interests of the country.
The hut used by the nomadic Indian tribes of the arid regionsof the west and southwest United States, typically elliptical inform, with a rough frame covered with reed mats or grass orbrushwood.
An American fresh-water mussel (Quadrula pustulosa). Its shellis used in making buttons.
A texture of osiers, twigs, or rods; articles made of such atexture.
See Wizard.
A box on the ear. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The capybara.
A European species of Iris (Iris Pseudacorus) having brightyellow flowers.
Wonderful. [Obs.] Gower.After that he said a wonder thing. Chaucer.
One who carries a wallet; a foot traveler; a tramping beggar.[Colloq.] Wright.
A book in which rough entries of transactions are made,previous to their being carried into the journal.
Whereas; while [Obs.]Whenas, if they would inquire into themselves, they would find nosuch matter. Barrow.
To wince; to shrink; to kick with impatience or uneasiness.
In a wrong manner; unjustly; erroneously; wrong; amiss; as, hejudges wrongly of my motives. "And yet wouldst wrongly win." Shak.
Employing, or done by means of, water or some other liquid; as,the wet extraction of copper, in distinction from dry extraction inwhich dry heat or fusion is employed.
As much as a wineglass will hold; enough to fill a wineglass.It is usually reckoned at two fluid ounces, or four tablespoonfuls.
To wriggle. [Obs.] Skelton.
An American tree, the winged elm. (Ulmus alata).
Having upright intentions or honorable purposes.Dutchmen who had sold themselves to France, as the wellintentionedparty. Macaulay.

Entitled to worship, reverence, or high respect; claimingrespect; worthy of honor; -- often used as a term of respect,sometimes ironically. "This is worshipful society." Shak.[She is] so dear and worshipful. Chaucer.-- Wor"ship*ful*ly, adv.-- Wor"ship*ful*ness, n.
A rare element supposed by Bahr to have been extracted fromwasite, but now identified with thorium.
Certainly; really; indeed. [Obs.] "As wis God helpe me."Chaucer.

The track left by a vessel in the water; by extension, anytrack; as, the wake of an army.This effect followed immediately in the wake of his earliestexertions. De Quincey.Several humbler persons . . . formed quite a procession in the dustywake of his chariot wheels. Thackeray.
To grow tired; to become exhausted or impatient; as, to wearyof an undertaking.
A cart carrying water; esp., one carrying water for sale, orfor sprinkling streets, gardens, etc.
Woe. [Obs.]
Good-natured; kind.Well-natured, temperate, and wise. Denham.
p. p. of Wreak. Chaucer.
Being without a wench. Shak.
In a wordy manner.
Like a woman; womanly.Womanlike, taking revenge too deep. Tennyson.
In a wondering manner.
A dark blue scombroid food fish (Acanthocibium solandri orpetus) of Florida and the West Indies.
a. & n. from Wean, v.The weaning of the whelp is the great test of the skill of the kennelman. J. H. Walsh.Weaning brash. (Med.) See under Brash.

A trick or stratagem practiced for insnaring or deception; asly, insidious; artifice; a beguilement; an allurement.Put on the whole armor of God, that ye may be able to stand againstthe wiles of the devil. Eph. vi. 11.Not more almighty to resist our might, Than wise to frustrate all ourplots and wiles. Milton.
Outdoor; exterior. [Obs.] "Her without-door form." Shak.
To soak water; to fill the interstices of with water.
Loss by use, decay, evaporation, leakage, or the like; waste.
A stone bass.
A mill operated by the power of the wind, usually by the actionof the wind upon oblique vanes or sails which radiate from ahorizontal shaft. Chaucer.
To breathe hard, and with an audible piping or whistling sound,as persons affected with asthma. "Wheezing lungs." Shak.
See Anacharis.
Hubbub. [Obs.] Shak.
Wise; sensible. [R.] Chapman.
See Pane, n., (3) b. [In this sense, written also window pane.]
The European goatsucker. [Prov. Eng.]
To flatter; to coax; to cajole.

An appendage to the shield, placed above it, and supporting thecrest (see Illust. of Crest). It generally represents a twist of twocords of silk, one tinctured like the principal metal, the other likethe principal color in the arms.
Causing wreck; involving ruin; destructive. "By wreckful wind."Spenser.
An old man; a graybeard.
To refuse. [Written also wern, worn.] [Obs.] Chaucer.
A kind of bur marigold (Bidens tripartita) found in wet placesin Europe.
the material of which wicks are made; esp., a loosely braidedor twisted cord or tape of cotton.
Wariness. [Obs.] Spenser.
The prairie dog.
Furnished with weapons, or arms; armed; equipped.
To be intewoven or entwined; to twine together; as, a bower ofwreathing trees. Dryden.
The glowing effect which arises from the use of warm colors;hence, any similar appearance or effect in a painting, or work ofcolor.
An aquatic kind of buttercup (Ranunculus aquatilis), used asfood for cattle in parts of England. Great water crowfoot, anAmerican water plant (Ranunculus multifidus), having deep yellowflowers.
Resembling that which is wise or sensible; judicious.The only wise-like thing I heard anybody say. Sir W. Scott.
A little worm.O dusty wormling! dost thou strive and stand With heaven's highmonarch Sylvester.
The vertebræ of the back. [Prov. Eng.] Dunglison.
A basin, or bowl, to hold water for washing one's hands, face,etc.
A salt of wolframic acid; a tungstate.
See Wormil.
One who wagers, or lays a bet.
In a weary manner.
Having the toes united by a web for a considerable part oftheir length.
Water flavored, sweetened, and frozen, to be eaten as aconfection.

Full of wiles, tricks, or stratagems; using craft or stratagemto accomplish a purpose; mischievously artful; subtle. "Wily andwise." Chaucer. "The wily snake." Milton.This false, wily, doubling disposition of mind. South.
Skill and practice in anything pertaining to the woods,especially in shooting, and other sports in the woods.Men of the glade and forest! leave Your woodcraft for the field offight. Bryant.
The advantage of using water as a mechanical power; also, theplace where water is, or may be, so used. See under Privilege.
In a whist manner; silently. [Obs.]
The quality of being worthy to be worshiped. [R.] Coleridge.
Having little crossings or openings like the sashes of awindow. [R.] Donne.
See 2d & 3d Wreak.
A deity corresponding to Odin, the supreme deity of theScandinavians. Wednesday is named for him. See Odin.
Hazarding; pertaining to the act of one who wagers. Wageringpolicy. (Com.) See Wager policy, under Policy.
The water spider.
One who wishes another well; one who is benevolently orfriendlily inclined.
Wept. Chaucer.
To nail boards upon so as to lap one over another, in order toexclude rain, snow, etc. Gwilt.
Having a left-hand twist; -- said of cordage; as, a water-laid,or left-hand, rope.
One who drinks much wine. Prov. xxiii. 20.-- Wine"bib`bing, n.
The nuthatch. [Prov. Eng.]
The possessive case of who or which. See Who, and Which.Whose daughter art thou tell me, I pray thee. Gen. xxiv. 23.The question whose solution I require. Dryden.
A collection of words; a vocabulary; a dictionary; a lexicon.
A sack or bag of wool; specifically, the seat of the lordchancellor of England in the House of Lords, being a large, squaresack of wool resembling a divan in form.
imp. & p. p. of Wring.
The spotted flycatcher. It builds its nest on walls. [Prov.Eng.]

Clothed with a fine, curly pubescence resembling wool. Woollybear (Zoöl.), the hairy larva of several species of bombycid moths.The most common species in the United States are the salt-marshcaterpillar (see under Salt), the black and red woolly bear, or larvaof the Isabella moth (see Illust., under Isabella Moth), and theyellow woolly bear, or larva of the American ermine moth (SpilosomaVirginica).-- Woolly butt (Bot.), an Australian tree (Eucalyptus longifolia),so named because of its fibrous bark.-- Woolly louse (Zoöl.), a plant louse (Schizoneura, or Erisoma,lanigera) which is often very injurious to the apple tree. It iscovered with a dense coat of white filaments somewhat resembling finewool or cotton. In exists in two forms, one of which infests theroots, the other the branches. See Illust. under Blight.-- Woolly macaco (Zoöl.), the mongoose lemur.-- Woolly maki (Zoöl.), a long-tailed lemur (Indris laniger) nativeof Madagascar, having fur somewhat like wool; -- called also avahi,and woolly lemur.-- Woolly monkey (Zoöl.), any South American monkey of the genusLagothrix, as the caparro.-- Woolly rhinoceros (Paleon.), an extinct rhinoceros (Rhinocerostichorhinus) which inhabited the arctic regions, and was covered witha dense coat of woolly hair. It has been found frozen in the ice ofSiberia, with the flesh and hair well preserved.
The passage for the breath from the larynx to the lungs; thetrachea; the weasand. See Illust. under Lung.
Lying farthest to the west; westernmost.
A bastard; colloquially, a low, scurvy fellow; -- usedgenerally in contempt, or in coarse humor. Also used adjectively.[Archaic] Shak.
A game at cards; whist. [Obs.] Taylor (1630).

Any botfly larva which burrows in or beneath the skin ofdomestic and wild animals, thus producing sores. They belong tovarious species of Hypoderma and allied genera. Domestic cattle areoften infested by a large species. See Gadfly. Called also warble,and worble. [Written also wormal, wormul, and wornil.]
A variety of allanite from Sweden supposed to contain wasium.
To grow white; to turn or become white or whiter; as, the hairwhitens with age; the sea whitens with foam; the trees in springwhiten with blossoms.

A corruption of Way, used only in the phrase under weigh.An expedition was got under weigh from New York. Thackeray.The Athenians . . . hurried on board and with considerable difficultygot under weigh. Jowett (Thucyd.).

A woman who has lost her husband by death, and has not marriedagain; one living bereaved of a husband. "A poor widow." Chaucer.Grass widow. See under Grass.-- Widow bewitched, a woman separated from her husband; a grasswidow. [Colloq.] Widow-in-mourning (Zoöl.), the macavahu.-- Widow monkey (Zoöl.), a small South American monkey (Callithrixlugens); -- so called on account of its color, which is black exceptthe dull whitish arms, neck, and face, and a ring of pure whitearound the face.-- Widow's chamber (Eng. Law), in London, the apparel and furnitureof the bedchamber of the widow of a freeman, to which she wasformerly entitled.
The wane of the moon. [Obs.] Halliwell.

W, the twenty-third letter of the English alphabet, is usuallya consonant, but sometimes it is a vowel, forming the second elementof certain diphthongs, as in few, how. It takes its written form andits name from the repetition of a V, this being the original form ofthe Roman capital letter which we call U. Etymologically it is mostrelated to v and u. See V, and U. Some of the uneducated classes inEngland, especially in London, confuse w and v, substituting the onefor the other, as weal for veal, and veal for weal; wine for vine,and vine for wine, etc. See Guide to Pronunciation, §§ 266-268.
A kind of stand, or piece of furniture, having shelves forbooks, ornaments, etc.; an étagère.
The conduct or principle of the Whiteboys.
Full of work; diligent. [R.]
Any aquatic mammal of the order Cetacea, especially any one ofthe large species, some of which become nearly one hundred feet long.Whales are hunted chiefly for their oil and baleen, or whalebone.
The quality or state of being weird.
The standard unit of electrical quantity, and also of current.See Coulomb, and Amp. [Obs.]
Of or pertaining to a weald, esp. to the weald in the county ofKent, England. [Obs.] Fuller.
The day following Whitmonday; -- called also Whitsun Tuesday.
An engine to raise water; or an engine moved by water; also, anengine or machine for extinguishing fires; a fire engine.
A small American hare or rabbit (Lepus aquaticus) found on ornear the southern coasts of the United States; -- called also waterrabbit, and swamp hare.
(Zoöl.) A Brazilian fly whose larvæ live in the skin of man andanimals, producing painful sores.
A board set up to windward in a boat, to keep out water. Ham.Nav. Encyc.
Weapon. [Obs.]
A nematode worm (Trichocephalus dispar) often found parasiticin the human intestine. Its body is thickened posteriorly, but isvery long and threadlike anteriorly.

To be; to become; to betide; -- now used only in the phrases,woe worth the day, woe worth the man, etc., in which the verb is inthe imperative, and the nouns day, man, etc., are in the dative. Woebe to the day, woe be to the man, etc., are equivalent phrases.I counsel . . . to let the cat worthe. Piers Plowman.He worth upon [got upon] his steed gray. Chaucer.

An instrument for measuring the distance which one has traveledon the road; an odometer, pedometer, or perambulator.The waywiser to a coach, exactly measuring the miles, and showingthem by an index. Evelyn.
See Warye. [Obs.]
A sort of apple.
The sin of worshiping idols; idolatry.O Ephraim, thou committest whoredom, and Israel is defiled; they willnot . . . turn unto their God. Hos. v. 3, 4.

The smallest part or particle imaginable; a bit; a jot; aniota; -- generally used in an adverbial phrase in a negativesentence. "Samuel told him every whit." 1 Sam. iii. 18. "Every whitas great." South.So shall I no whit be behind in duty. Shak.It does not me a whit displease. Cowley.
In the manner of a wedge.
A horse imported from New South Wales; also, any Australianhorse. [Colloq.]  Kipling.

A device for regulating the temperature of anything subjectedto heat, by surrounding the vessel containing it with another vesselcontaining water which can be kept at a desired temperature; also, avessel designed for this purpose.
Hydraulic cement.

Any one of many species of Old World singing birds belonging toMotacilla and several allied genera of the family Motacillidæ. Theyhave the habit of constantly jerking their long tails up and down,whence the name. Field wagtail, any one of several species ofwagtails of the genus Budytes having the tail shorter, the legslonger, and the hind claw longer and straighter, than do the waterwagtails. Most of the species are yellow beneath. Called also yellowwagtail.-- Garden wagtail, the Indian black-breasted wagtail (NemoricolaIndica).-- Pied wagtail, the common European water wagtail (Motacillalugubris). It is variegated with black and white. The name is appliedalso to other allied species having similar colors. Called also pieddishwasher.-- Wagtail flycatcher, a true flycatcher (Sauloprocta motacilloides)common in Southern Australia, where it is very tame, and frequentsstock yards and gardens and often builds its nest about houses; --called also black fantail.-- Water wagtail. (a) Any one of several species of wagtails of therestricted genus Motacilla. They live chiefly on the shores of pondsand streams. (b) The American water thrush. See Water thrush.-- Wood wagtail, an Asiatic wagtail; (Calobates sulphurea) having aslender bill and short legs.
The redwing. [Prov. Eng.]
See Water gauge.
One who wins, or gains by success in competition, contest, orgaming.

An instrument for boring holes, turned by a handle.Specifically:(a) A gimlet. " It is but like the little wimble, to let in thegreater auger." Selden.(b) A stonecutter's brace for boring holes in stone.(c) An auger used for boring in earth.
Fiorin.
A dark brown or black mineral, occurring in prismatic crystalsimbedded in limestone near Warwick, New York. It consists of theborate and titanate of magnesia and iron.
Stop; stand; hold. See Ho, 2.
A diving, or water, beetle, especially the larva of a waterbeetle. See Illust. b of Water beetle.
A perennial, cruciferous plant (Cheiranthus Cheiri), withsweet-scented flowers varying in color from yellow to orange and deepred. In Europe it very common on old walls.
Any one of certain plants whose soft, downy leaves have beenused for dressing wounds, as the kidney vetch, and several species ofthe labiate genus Stachys.
Any one of numerous species of rails of the genus Rallus, asthe common European species (Rallus aquaticus). See Illust. of Rail.
A small shaft sunk from one level to another, as for thepurpose of ventilation.
The common sandpiper.
The male of the chaffinch. [Prov. Eng.]
A boat for conveying provisions, tools, etc.; -- so called byMaine lumbermen. [Written also wangun.] Bartlett.
A man who washes clothes, esp. for hire, or for others.
Thin; sharp; withered; wizened; as, a weazen face.They were weazen and shriveled. Dickens.
Not sleeping; indisposed to sleep; watchful; vigilant.Dissembling sleep, but wakeful with the fright. Dryden.-- Wake"ful*ly, adv.-- Wake"ful*ness, n.
A word of doubtful meaning used once by Shakespeare.This [gold] is itThat makes the wappen'd widow wed again.

A large, heavy antelope (Kobus ellipsiprymnus) native ofCentral Africa. It frequents the banks of rivers and is a goodswimmer. It has a white ring around the rump. Called also photomok,water antelope, and waterbok.
At which place; where. [Obs.] Chaucer.At last they came whereas that lady bode. Spenser.
The week commencing with Whitsunday, esp. the first three days-- Whitsunday, Whitsun Monday, and Whitsun Tuesday; the time ofPentecost. R. of Gloucester.
Same as Whall.
The spotted flycatcher. [Prov. Eng.]
A breeze fly.

Any one of several species of ticks of the genus Ixodes whoseyoung cling to bushes, but quickly fasten themselves upon the bodiesof any animal with which they come in contact. When they attachthemselves to the human body they often produce troublesome sores.The common species of the Northern United States is Ixodesunipunctata.
Same as Water course.
A unit of power or activity equal to 107 C.G.S. units of power,or to work done at the rate of one joule a second. An English horsepower is approximately equal to 746 watts.
By waiting.
The waxwing.
imp. & p. p. of Win.
In a willing manner; with free will; without reluctance;cheerfully. Chaucer.The condition of that people is not so much to be envied as somewould willingly represent it. Addison.
A kind of canvaslike cotton fabric, used to stiffen and protectthe lower part of trousers and of the skirts of women's dresses,etc.; -- so called from Wigan, the name of a town in Lancashire,England.
In a whimsical manner; freakishly.
One of the casks stowed in the wings of a vessel's hold, beingsmaller than such as are stowed more amidships. Totten.
A gate, or valve, by which a flow of water is permitted,prevented, or regulated.
Dyed before being made into cloth, in distinction from piece-dyed; ingrain.
The kestrel; -- called also windbibber, windcuffer, windfanner.[Prov. Eng.]
The characteristic of being winsome; attractiveness of manner.J. R. Green.
One who commits a tort or trespass; a trespasser; a tortfeasor. Ayliffe.
Authority; security; warranty. [Obs.] Shak.

In the United States navy, a first-class petty officer incharge in a fireroom. He "tends" water to the boilers, sees thatfires are properly cleaned and stoked, etc. There is also a rating ofchief water tender, who is a chief petty officer.
Capable of being washed off; not permanent or durable; -- saidof colors not fixed by steaming or otherwise.
Mad. See Wood, a. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.] Chaucer.
A name given to the "big trees" (Sequoia gigantea) ofCalifornia, and still used in England. See Sequoia.
A floating mass formed in pools by the entangled filaments of aEuropean fresh-water alga (Cladophora crispata).
Angry; vexed; wrathful. [Obs.]With this speech the cock wex wroth and wraw. Chaucer.
See Whort.
Dwelling. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A combination of wheels, and their connection, in a machine ormechanism.
The joint, or the region of the joint, between the hand and thearm; the carpus. See Carpus.He took me by the wrist, and held me hard. Shak.

A thin cake made of flour and other ingredients.Wafers piping hot out of the gleed. Chaucer.The curious work in pastry, the fine cakes, wafers, and marchpanes.Holland.A woman's oaths are wafers -- break with making B. Jonson.

a. & n. from Whirl, v. t. Whirling table. (a) (Physics) Anapparatus provided with one or more revolving disks, with weights,pulleys, and other attachments, for illustrating the phenomena andlaws of centrifugal force, and the like. (b) A potter's wheel.
The Australian white-quilled honey eater (Entomyza albipennis).
The kestrel. B. Jonson.
oWithstand.
A kind of pledge or mortgage. [Written also wadsett.]
In a wealthy manner; richly.I come to wive it wealthily in Padua. Shak.
A pirate. [R.] Shak.
The ladyfish (a).
To grow; to wax. [Obs.] Chaucer. "Each wexing moon." Dryden.
The draining off of water.
Being well folded. [Obs.] "Her well-plighted frock." Spenser.
A wretch. [Obs.]
The European widgeon. [Prov. Eng.]
a. & n. from Warm, v. Warming pan, a long-handled covered paninto which live coals are put, -- used for warming beds. Shak.
Absent; lacking; missing; also, deficient; destitute; needy;as, one of the twelve is wanting; I shall not be wanting in exertion.
In a whisper, or low voice; in a whispering manner; withwhispers. Tennyson.

To protect from the effects of; hence, to cure; to heal. [Obs.]My brother shall be warished hastily. Chaucer.Varro testifies that even at this day there be some who warish andcure the stinging of serpents with their spittle. Holland.

An African plant (Welwitschia mirabilis) belonging to the orderGnetaceæ. It consists of a short, woody, topshaped stem, and nevermore than two leaves, which are the cotyledons enormously developed,and at length split into diverging segments.
One who, or that which, wriggles. Cowper.
Warlike. Burns.

With; -- put after its object, at the end of sentence or clausein which it stands. [Obs.]This diamond he greets your wife withal. Shak.Whatsoever uncleanness it be that a man shall be defiled withal. Lev.v. 3.
A small South American monkey; a marmoset. [Written alsowistiti, and ouistiti.]
See Crookbill.
A vicious habit of a horse, consisting in the swallowing ofair; -- usually associated with crib-biting, or cribbing. SeeCribbing, 4.
The act of pulling the wires, as of a puppet; hence, secretinfluence or management, especially in politics; intrigue.
Acidulated whey, sometimes mixed with buttermilk and sweetherbs, used as a cooling beverage. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
One who, or that which, winces, shrinks, or kicks.
