The quality or state of being wild; an uncultivated or untamedstate; disposition to rove or go unrestrained; rudeness; savageness;irregularity; distraction.
Any one of numerous species of aquatic salamanders; a triton.
Wherever; -- a contracted and poetical form. Cowper.
Having little courage; of feeble spirit; dispirited; faint-hearted. "Weak-hearted enemies." Shak.
White with heat; heated to whiteness, or incandescence.
Widely; far and wide. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To utter the ordinary call or cry of a horse; to neigh.
Dressed in weeds, or mourning garments. [R. or Colloq.]She was as weedy as in the early days of her mourning. Dickens.
Any one of several species of kangaroos of the genus Macropus,especially M. robustus, sometimes called the great wallaroo.

An inflammation of the fingers or toes, generally of the lastphalanx, terminating usually in suppuration. The inflammation mayoccupy any seat between the skin and the bone, but is usually appliedto a felon or inflammation of the periosteal structures of the bone.
Having a close texture; dense; as, a woofy cloud. J. Baillie.
Having little knobs on the surface; verrucose; as, a wartedcapsule.
The process of cleansing wool, cotton, or the like, with awilly, or willow. Willying machine. Same as 1st Willow, 2
A South American monkey, one of the sapajous.
A mark to guide in traveling.
Quality or state of being weaned.

A witty saying; a sentence or phrase which is affectedly witty;an attempt at wit; a conceit. Milton.He is full of conceptions, points of epigram, and witticisms; allwhich are below the dignity of heroic verse. Addison.
The marysole, or sail fluke.
A species of large tupelo (Nyssa aquatica) growing in swamps inthe southern of the United States. See Ogeechee lime.
A dog accustomed to the water, or trained to retrievewaterfowl. Retrievers, waters spaniels, and Newfoundland dogs are sotrained.
Having no wood; destitute of wood. Mitford.-- Wood"less*ness, n.
A covering of canvas or tarpaulin for the hammocks, stowed onthe nettings, between the quarterdeck and the forecastle.
The act or process of binding or platting with twigs; also, thenetwork so formed.Made with a wattling of canes or sticks. Dampier.
One who, or that which, feeds on or destroys wit. [Obs.] B.Jonson.
See 2d Will. [Obs.]
Given to sensual indulgence; gluttonous. [Obs.] Joye.
The act of winding or turning; a turn; a bend; a twist; awinding.
See Ignis fatuus.
To cause to shake; to tremble; to move tremulously, as fromweakness; to totter. [Obs.]
To supply with a weathercock; to serve as a weathercock for.Whose blazing wyvern weathercock the spire. Tennyson.
A man who owns, or has the care of, a wharf.
Prosperity; happiness; well-being; weal. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The revival of an action. Burrill.They were too much ashamed to bring any wakening of the processagainst Janet. Sir W. Scott.
The American golden-eye.
Avenger. [Obs.]The stork, the wrekere of avouterye [adultery]. Chaucer.
The act or process of waning, or decreasing.This earthly moon, the Church, hath fulls and wanings, and sometimesher eclipses. Bp. Hall.
Driven by winds or storms; forced by stress of weather. Carew.
See Valhalla.
Wifehood. [Obs.] Spenser.
To twist or contort the body; to be distorted; as, to writhewith agony. Also used figuratively.After every attempt, he felt that he had failed, and writhed withshame and vexation. Macaulay.
A sharp or uneven edge on a board that is cut from a log notperfectly squared, or that is made in the process of squaring. SeeWany, a.
The lash of a whip, -- usually made of thongs of leather, or ofcords, braided or twisted.
The objective of whosoever. See Whosoever.The Most High ruleth in the kingdow of men, and giveth it towhomsoever he will. Dan. iv. 17.
The curlew. [Prov. Eng.]
Weleful. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A covering for the wrist.
Having the toes united by a membrane, or web; as, the webbedfeet of aquatic fowls.
A weanling; a young child.I, being but a yearling wean. Mrs. Browning.
A coarse yellow-flowered plant (Nasturtium amphibium) relatedto the water cress and to the horse-radish.
Thin and pale; weak; without strength or substance; --originally said of liquids. Fig., weak-minded; spiritless.A weak wishy-washy man who had hardly any mind of his own. A.Trollope.
The witch-hazel.
One who pulls the wires, as of a puppet; hence, one whooperates by secret means; an intriguer.Political wire-pullers and convention packers. Lowell.
Having (such) wool; as, a fine-wooled sheep.
To wane; to wither. [Obs.]
Tungstate of iron and manganese, generally of a brownish orgrayish black color, submetallic luster, and high specific gravity.It occurs in cleavable masses, and also crystallized. Called alsowolfram.
The sailfish.
Extended throughout the world; as, world-wide fame. Tennyson.
The quality or state of being wavy.

a. & n. from Weigh, v. Weighing cage, a cage in which smallliving animals may be conveniently weighed.-- Weighing house. See Weigh-house.-- Weighing machine, any large machine or apparatus for weighing;especially, platform scales arranged for weighing heavy bodies, asloaded wagons.
See Weasel.
Expanding into a flat, circular border at top, with scarcelyany tube; as, a wheel-shaped corolla.

Which (of two); which one (of two); -- used interrogatively andrelatively. [Archaic]Now choose yourself whether that you liketh. Chaucer.One day in doubt I cast for to compare Whether in beauties' glory didexceed. Spenser.Whether of them twain did the will of his father Matt. xxi. 31.

A gun in the construction of which an inner tube (either entireor in segments) is wound with wire under tension to insure greatersoundness and uniformity of resistance. In modern construction hoopsand jackets are shrunk on over the wire.
See 4th Ware.

Accustomed; customary; usual.Again his wonted weapon proved. Spenser.Like an old piece of furniture left alone in its wonted corner. SirW. Scott.She was wonted to the place, and would not remove. L'Estrange.
imp. & p. p. of Wend; -- now obsolete except as the imperfectof go, with which it has no etymological connection. See Go.To the church both be they went. Chaucer.
See Valkyria.
A summit from the opposite sides of which rain waters flow todifferent streams; a line separating the drainage districts of twostreams or coasts; a divide.
A wood seller. [Obs.]
In a worrying manner.
Ability or capacity to write. [R.] Walpole.
Disordered or unsettled in intellect; deranged. [Scot.] Sir W.Scott.
See Waul. Shak.
Causing waste; also, undergoing waste; diminishing; as, awasting disease; a wasting fortune. Wasting palsy (Med.), progressivemuscular atrophy. See under Progressive.
The osier willow (Salix viminalis). See Osier, n. (a).
Any plant of the American genus Hydrophyllum, herbs havingwhite or pale blue bell-shaped flowers. Gray.

A compensation given to a hired person for services; price paidfor labor; recompense; hire. See Wage, n., 2.The wages of sin is death. Rom. vi. 23.Wages fund (Polit. Econ.), the aggregate capital existing at any timein any country, which theoretically is unconditionally destined to bepaid out in wages. It was formerly held, by Mill and other politicaleconomists, that the average rate of wages in any country at any timedepended upon the relation of the wages fund to the number oflaborers. This theory has been greatly modified by the discovery ofother conditions affecting wages, which it does not take intoaccount. Encyc. Brit.
Barium carbonate occurring in white or gray six-sided twincrystals, and also in columnar or granular masses.

To utter a plaintive cry, as some animals; to mean with achildish noise; to complain, or to tell of sorrow, distress, or thelike, in a plaintive, nasal tone; hence, to complain or to beg in amean, unmanly way; to moan basely. "Whining plovers." Spenser.The hounds were . . . staying their coming, but with a whiningaccent, craving liberty. Sir P. Sidney.Dost thou come here to whine Shak.
The lesser spotted woodpecker (Dryobates minor). [Prov. Eng.]
A steam vessel propelled by a paddle wheel or by paddle wheels;-- used chiefly in the terms side-wheeler and stern-wheeler.
Having an undivided hoof, as the horse.
See Windlass. [Obs.]Two arblasts, . . . with windlaces and quarrels. Sir W. Scott.
To warray. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Unwary; incautious; unheeding; careless; unaware. [Obs.]And wareless of the evil That by themselves unto themselves iswrought. Spenser.
Warworn.
See Weld.
A wild or unfrequented wood. Also used adjectively; as,wildwood flowers; wildwood echoes. Burns.
Reckless; hence, disregarded. [Obs.] -- Wretch"less*ly, adv.[Obs.] -- Wretch"less*ness, n. [Obs.] Bk. of Com. Prayer.Your deaf ears should listen Unto the wretchless clamors of the poor.J. Webster.
A fruit bat (Pteropus medius) native of India. It is similar tothe flying fox, but smaller.

A large mass of tough sinewy substance in the head of spermwhales, just above the upper jaw and extending in streaks into thejunk above it. It resembles blubber, but contains no oil. Also, thepart of the head in which it occurs.

a. & n. from Whistle, v. Whistling buoy. (Naut.) See underBuoy.-- Whistling coot (Zoöl.), the American black scoter.-- Whistling Dick. (Zoöl.) (a) An Australian shrike thrush(Colluricincla Selbii). (b) The song thrush. [Prov. Eng.] --Whistling duck. (Zoöl.) (a) The golden-eye. (b) A tree duck.-- Whistling eagle (Zoöl.), a small Australian eagle (Haliastursphenurus); -- called also whistling hawk, and little swamp eagle.-- Whistling plover. (Zoöl.) (a) The golden plover. (b) The black-bellied, or gray, plover.-- Whistling snipe (Zoöl.), the American woodcock.-- Whistling swan. (Zoöl.) (a) The European whooper swan; -- calledalso wild swan, and elk. (b) An American swan (Olor columbianus). Seeunder Swan.-- Whistling teal (Zoöl.), a tree duck, as Dendrocygna awsuree ofIndia.-- Whistling thrush. (Zoöl.) (a) Any one of several species ofsinging birds of the genus Myiophonus, native of Asia, Australia, andthe East Indies. They are generally black, glossed with blue, andhave a patch of bright blue on each shoulder. Their note is a loudand clear whistle. (b) The song thrush. [Prov. Eng.]

a. & n. from Water, v. Watering call (Mil.), a sound of trumpetor bugle summoning cavalry soldiers to assemble for the purpose ofwatering their horses.-- Watering cart, a sprinkling cart. See Water.-- Watering place. (a) A place where water may be obtained, as for aship, for cattle, etc. (b) A place where there are springs ofmedicinal water, or a place by the sea, or by some large body ofwater, to which people resort for bathing, recreation, boating, etc.-- Watering pot. (a) A kind of bucket fitted with a rose, orperforated nozzle, -- used for watering flowers, paths, etc. (b)(Zoöl.) Any one of several species of marine bivalve shells of thegenus Aspergillum, or Brechites. The valves are small, andconsolidated with the capacious calcareous tube which incases theentire animal. The tube is closed at the anterior end by a convexdisk perforated by numerous pores, or tubules, and resembling therose of a watering pot.-- Watering trough, a trough from which cattle, horses, and otheranimals drink.
One who whimpers.
A covering of painting canvas for the equipments of a dragoon'shorse. Wilhelm.
Same as Hurons. [Written also Wyandottes, and Yendots.]
The act, or the process, of gilding metallic surfaces bycovering them with a thin coating of amalgam of gold, and thenvolatilizing the mercury by heat; -- called also wash gilding.
Capable of being welded.
An American bird (Antrostomus vociferus) allied to thenighthawk and goatsucker; -- so called in imitation of the peculiarnotes which it utters in the evening. [Written also whippowil.]
Destitute of water; dry. Chaucer.
One whose business it is to weigh ore, hay, merchandise, etc.;one licensed as a public weigher.
Unrevengeful; weak. [Obs.]
The tire of a wheel.
A cruciferous plant (Nasturtium sylvestre) with small yellowflowers.
A Whig; -- a cant term applied in contempt to ScotchPresbyterians. [Scot.] Sir W. Scott.
Worth the time or effort spent. See worth while. worthy.-- worthwhileness.
Worn with military service; as, a warworn soldier; a warworncoat. Shak.
The quality or state of being wealthy, or rich; richness;opulence.
To travel over without a certain course; to traverse; to strollthrough. [R.] "[Elijah] wandered this barren waste." Milton.
A mendicant monk of the Carmelite order, so called from thewhite cloaks worn by the order. See Carmelite.
Willow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A hole or excavation in the earth, in mining, from which runbranches or galleries.
A form of self-propelling torpedo.
A New Zealand rail (Ocydromus australis) which has wings soshort as to be incapable of flight.
The yaffle. [Prov. Eng.]
So tight as to retain, or not to admit, water; not leaky.
The hoary, or northern, marmot (Arctomys pruinosus).

The act of placing goods in a warehouse, or in a customhousestore. Warehousing system, an arrangement for lodging importedarticles in the customhouse stores, without payment of duties untilthey are taken out for home consumption. If reëxported, they are notcharged with a duty. See Bonded warehouse, under Bonded, a.
One who wanders; a rambler; one who roves; hence, one whodeviates from duty.
p. pr. & rare vb. n. of Weave.
One who, or that which, weeds, or frees from anything noxious.
A vireo (Vireo altiloquus) native of the West Indies andFlorida; -- called also black-whiskered vireo.
See under Hemp.
Having a pale or white face, as from fright. "Whey-facedcavaliers." Aytoun.
A heavy wooden hammer for milling cloth.
The quality or state of being wily; craftiness; cunning; guile.
An Australian lorikeet (Ptilosclera versicolor) noted for thevariety of its colors; -- called also varied lorikeet.
Capable of being wielded.

A venomous North American snake (Ancistrodon piscivorus) alliedto the rattlesnake but destitute of a rattle. It lives in or aboutpools and ponds, and feeds largely of fishes. Called also watersnake, water adder, water viper.

A gambling or lottery device consisting of a wheel which isspun horizontally, articles or sums to which certain marks on itscircumference point when it stops being distributed according tovarying rules.
Work, especially openwork, formed of wires.
The act or manner of expressing in words; style of expression;phrasing.It is believed this wording was above his known style. Milton.
An imaginary creature, of undefined character. [Slang]
Same as Water mite.
According to desire; longingly; with wishes. [Obs. or Prov.Eng.] Chapman.
Weather. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A weasel. [Scot.]
See Wastrel. [Obs.]
A pledge; a pawn. [Obs.] Gower. Piers Plowman.Let him be ware, his neck lieth to wed [i. e., for a security].Chaucer.
See Wayz-goose, n., 2. [Eng.]
To work [Obs.] Chaucer.
A nurse who suckles a child, especially the child of anotherwoman. Cf. Dry nurse.
Conveyance by means of a wagon or wagons. [Obs.] Milton.

The higher literary idiom of Chinese, that of the canonicalbooks and of all composition pretending to literary standing. Itemploys a classical or academic diction, and a more condensed andsententious style than Mandarin, and differs also in the doubling andarrangement of words.
Sick at the stomach; also, crestfallen; dejected. [Slang]
See Yuen.
, a. Having the head covered with a wig; wearing a wig.
Time during which one is awake. [R.] Mrs. Browning.
A bar attached to the tiller, for convenience in steering.

A small European singing bird (Saxicola oenanthe). The male iswhite beneath, bluish gray above, with black wings and a black stripethrough each eye. The tail is black at the tip and in the middle, butwhite at the base and on each side. Called also checkbird, chickell,dykehopper, fallow chat, fallow finch, stonechat, and whitetail.
A young heifer. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.
A bench on which work is performed, as in a carpenter's shop.
To choose; to select. [Obs.] "Wailed wine and meats." Henryson.
To involve in a quarrel or dispute; to embroil. [R.] Bp.Sanderson.
To neigh; to whinny. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
A passage for water, such as was usually made in a sea wall, todrain water out of marshes. Burrill.
See Wou-wou.
One who wrestles; one who is skillful in wrestling.
A religious meeting held in the closing hours of the year.
Capable of being weighed.
The females of the human race; women, collectively.A sanctuary into which womankind, with her tools of magic, the broomand mop, has very infrequent access. Hawthorne.

Giving previous notice; cautioning; admonishing; as, a warningvoice.That warning timepiece never ceased. Longfellow.Warning piece, Warning wheel (Horol.), a piece or wheel whichproduces a sound shortly before the clock strikes.
A stick used to tighten the rope in woolding.
In a warbling manner.
See Wayment. [Obs.]
A silicate of lime of a white to gray, red, or yellow color,occurring generally in cleavable masses, rarely in tabular crystals;tabular spar.

A kind of fine pottery, the most remarkable being what iscalled jasper, either white, or colored throughout the body, andcapable of being molded into the most delicate forms, so that fineand minute bas-reliefs like cameos were made of it, fit even forbeing set as jewels.
A dog kept to watch and guard premises or property, and to givenotice of the approach of intruders.
One who wails or laments.
A veal cutlet variously seasoned garnished, often with lemon,sardines, and capers.
To roll or wallow; to welter. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Whence. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To lash with stripes; to wale; to thrash; to drub. [Prov. Eng.& Colloq. U. S.] Halliwell. Bartlett.
A mode of facing sea walls and embankments with planks drivenas piles and secured by ties. Knight.
A small warbler (Pratincola rubetra) common in Europe; --called also whinchacker, whincheck, whin-clocharet.
See Weever.
One who wavers; one who is unsettled in doctrine, faith,opinion, or the like. Shak.

A joint in a stone pavement where the stones are left slightlyhigher than elsewhere, the rest of the surface being sunken ordished. The raised surface is intended to prevent the settling ofwater in the joints.
A window. [Obs.] Hudibras.
A storehouse for wares, or goods. Addison.
Lying toward the west.Yond same star that's westward from the pole. Shak.
In a winking manner; with the eye almost closed. Peacham.
To wield. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Woad. [Obs.] Mortimer.
A sound like a half-formed whistle, expressing astonishment,scorn, or dislike. Whew duck, the European widgeon. [Prov. Eng.]
Supplied or covered with wood, or trees; as, land wooded andwatered.The brook escaped from the eye down a deep and wooded dell. Sir W.Scott.
Not to be depended on; weak; unstable. [Prov. Eng.] Grose.

Anciently, a meeting of the inhabitants of a ward; also, acourt formerly held in each ward of London for trying defaults inmatters relating to the watch, police, and the like. Brande & C."Wards and wardmotes." Piers Plowman.
Having (such) a wit or understanding; as, a quick-witted boy.
An acute infectious febrile disease, resembling typhoid fever,with muscular pains, disturbance of the digestive organs, jaundice,etc.
A light-colored highly effervescent beer made by the top-fermentation process.

A man of eminent worth or value; one distinguished for usefuland estimable qualities; a person of conspicuous desert; -- much usedin the plural; as, the worthies of the church; political worthies;military worthies.The blood of ancient worthies in his veins. Cowper.
Correctly informed; provided with information; well furnishedwith authentic knowledge; intelligent.

A Romanic people inhabiting that part of Belgium whichcomprises the provinces of Hainaut, Namur, Liége, and Luxembourg, andabout one third of Brabant; also, the language spoken by this people.Used also adjectively. [Written also Wallons.] "A base Walloon . . .thrust Talbot with a spear." Shak. Walloon guard, the bodyguard ofthe Spanish monarch; -- so called because formerly consisting ofWalloons.
The cornel tree. Chaucer.
Fit for war. [Obs.] "Warhable youth." Spenser.

Within; inside; inwardly. [Obs.] Wyclif.[It is much greater] labor for to withinforth call into mind, withoutsight of the eye withoutforth upon images, what he before knew andthought upon. Bp. Peacock.
The whimbrel.
The European blackbird. "The woofell near at hand that hath agolden bill." Drayton.
A measure formerly used for articles brought by water, ascoals, oysters, etc. The water-measure bushel was three gallonslarger than the Winchester bushel. Cowell.
That which is wanting; deficiency.
See Wanghee.
To whisk along quickly; to hurry. [R.]Whurrying the chariot with them to the shore. Vicars.
According to wish; conformably to desire. [Obs.] Chapman.
To dwell; to abide. [Obs.] Piers Plowman.Their habitation in which they woned. Chaucer.
An arrangement of a woman's back hair over a cushion or framein some resemblance to a waterfall.
A sale made in washing. See Washing, n., 3, above.
An instrument for measuring power in watts, -- much used inmeasuring the energy of an electric current.

One of the broad, thin, anterior lobes of the foot of apteropod, used as an organ in swimming.(b) (Bot.) Any membranaceous expansion, as that along the sides ofcertain stems, or of a fruit of the kind called samara.(c) (Bot.) Either of the two side petals of a papilionaceous flower.
Free from anger or wrath. Waller.
Fully known; generally known or acknowledged.A church well known with a well-known rite. M. Arnold.
A young whiting. [Prov. Eng.]
Wintry.
See Wimple.
Not wrong; void or free from wrong. [Obs.] -- Wrong"less*ly,adv. [Obs.] Sir P. Sidney.
A large metal pipe made to be extended vertically by sections,and used for discharging water upon burning buildings.
Treatment with whey as a drink and in baths.
Proof against rough weather.
See Wondrous. [Obs.]They be wonders glad thereof. Sir T. More.
Not right; illegal; as, wrongous imprisonment. Craig.
Full of whims; whimsical.The study of Rabbinical literature either finds a man whimmy or makeshim so. Coleridge.
A kind of long boots for men.
The quality or state of being watery; moisture; humidity.
To cry as a cat; to squall; to wail. [Written also wawl.]The helpless infant, coming wauling and crying into the world. Sir W.Scott.
Disturbance of the stomach; a feeling of nausea. Holland.
A woodpecker. [Obs.]
An aquatic American plant (Brasenia peltata) having floatingoval leaves, and the covered with a clear jelly.
During the time that; while. [Archaic] Chaucer. Fuller.Agree with thine adversary quickly, whiles thou art in the way withhim. Matt. v. 25.
Formed of a wisp, or of wisp; as, a wispen broom. [Obs.]
One who wakes.
The technical name of the element tungsten. See Tungsten.
Become wild. [R.]An old garden plant escaped and wilded. J. Earle.
To censure or rebuke; to hold up to reprobation; to scold.[Slang]
A hydrometer.
Having too rank or forward a growth for winter.When either corn is winter-proud, or other plants put forth and budtoo early. Holland.
Same as Whisky, a liquor.
Pertaining to, or characteristic of, working days, or workdays;everyday; hence, plodding; hard-working.O, how full of briers in this working-day world. Shak.
The windowpane (Pleuronectes maculatus). [Local, U. S.]
Any one of several species of large, elongated, marine fishesof the genus Cryptacanthodes, especially C. maculatus of the Americancoast. A whitish variety is called ghostfish.
The office, province, or jurisdiction of a waywode.
A small sail sometimes set under a studding sail or under adriver boom, and reaching nearly to the water.
Whitlow. [Obs.] "The nails fallen off by whitflaws." Herrick.
One who, or that which, wounds.

Anything moved with a whirl, as preparatory for a blow, or toaugment the force of it; -- applied by poets to the cestus of ancientboxers.The whirlbat and the rapid race shall be Reserved for Cæsar. Dryden.
The time when there no sap in the trees; the winter season.[Written also wood-seer.] [Obs.] Tusser.
Same as Whetile.
Running without control; running along the line without atrain; as, a wild-cat locomotive.

One who is engaged in a mechanical or manufacturing business;an artificer; a workman; a manufacturer; a mechanic; esp., a workerin wood; -- now chiefly used in compounds, as in millwright,wheelwright, etc.He was a well good wright, a carpenter. Chaucer.

A common large North American marmot (Arctomys monax). It isusually reddish brown, more or less grizzled with gray. It makesextensive burrows, and is often injurious to growing crops. Calledalso ground hog.
Having a white front; as, the white-fronted lemur. White-fronted goose (Zoöl.), the white brant, or snow goose. See Snowgoose, under Snow.
A female warrior. [Obs.] Spenser.
An Australian lorikeet (Trichoglossus multicolor) remarkablefor the variety and brilliancy of its colors; -- called also blue-bellied lorikeet, and blue-bellied parrot.
Whether one or another; whether one or the other; which; thatone (of two or more) which; as, whichever road you take, it will leadyou to town.
The act of one who weeps; lamentation with tears; shedding oftears.
A duty or toil paid for weighing merchandise. Bouvier.
imp. of Will. See Would.
Any vessel or boat plying on water; vessels and boats,collectively.
To wrinkle. [Obs.] Spenser.
A small glass from to drink wine.
To cause (the eyes) to wink.[Colloq.]
Commonly used as an auxiliary verb, either in the past tense orin the conditional or optative present. See 2d & 3d Will.
Unaccustomed. [Obs.] Spenser.
Valor tried by war.
A whirling blast or wind.A whirl-blast from behind the hill. Wordsworth.
A goddess of any stream or other body of water, whether one ofthe Naiads, Nereids, or Oceanides.
, pl of Wife.
The office of a writer.
Same as Whap. Forby.
Power; authority; rule. [Obs.]To have them in your might and in your wielding. Chaucer.
A kind of wash bottle with two or three necks; -- so calledafter the inventor, Peter Woulfe, an English chemist.
Colored or stained with woad. "Man tattoed or woaded, winter-clad in skins." Tennyson.

Cerumen, or earwax. See Cerumen.(b) A waxlike composition used for uniting surfaces, for excludingair, and for other purposes; as, sealing wax, grafting wax, etchingwax, etc.(c) A waxlike composition used by shoemakers for rubbing theirthread.(d) (Zoöl.) A substance similar to beeswax, secreted by severalspecies of scale insects, as the Chinese wax. See Wax insect, below.(e) (Bot.) A waxlike product secreted by certain plants. SeeVegetable wax, under Vegetable. (f) (Min.)
See Wigwam. [R.]
To make wide or wider; to extend in breadth; to increase thewidth of; as, to widen a field; to widen a breach; to widen astocking.

A person transformed into a wolf in form and appetite, eithertemporarily or permanently, whether by supernatural influences, bywitchcraft, or voluntarily; a lycanthrope. Belief in werewolves,formerly general, is not now extinct.The werwolf went about his prey. William of Palerne.The brutes that wear our form and face, The werewolves of the humanrace. Longfellow.
Breathing with difficulty and with a wheeze; wheezing. Usedalso figuratively.
A kind of large steelyard for weighing merchandise; -- alsocalled weighmaster's beam.
An exhibition of wax figures, or the place of exhibition.
Being without whiskers.
A windrow.
The chaffinch, whose cry is thought to foretell rain. [Prov.Eng.]
See Wallachian.

Having a tail which has the middle pair of feathers longest,the rest successively and decidedly shorter, and all more or lessattenuate; -- said of certain birds. See Illust. of Wood hoopoe,under Wood. Wedge-tailed eagle, an Australian eagle (Aquila audax)which feeds on various small species of kangaroos, and on lambs; --called also mountain eagle, bold eagle, and eagle hawk.-- Wedge-tailed gull, an arctic gull (Rhodostethia rosea) in whichthe plumage is tinged with rose; -- called also Ross's gull.
Capable of being worshiped; worthy of worship. [R.] Carlyle.

One wearing a waistcoat; esp., a woman wearing one uncovered,or thought fit for such a habit; hence, a loose woman; strumpet.[Obs.]Do you think you are here, sir, Amongst your waistcoateers, your basewenches Beau. & Fl.
To lament; to grieve; to wail. [Written also waiment.] [Obs.]Thilke science . . . maketh a man to waymenten. Chaucer.For what boots it to weep and wayment, When ill is chanced Spenser.
The meadow pipit. [Prov. Eng.]
A basket for holding materials for needlework, or the like.
The quality or state of being accustomed. [R.] Eikon Basilike.

A covenant real, whereby the grantor of an estate of freeholdand his heirs were bound to warrant and defend the title, and, incase of eviction by title paramount, to yield other lands of equalvalue in recompense. This warranty has long singe become obsolete,and its place supplied by personal covenants for title. Among theseis the covenant of warranty, which runs with the land, and is in thenature of a real covenant. Kent.
In what direction; toward what or which place. R. of Brunne.Whitherward to turn for a good course of life was by no means tooapparent. Carlyle.
A long, narrow boat, sharp at both ends, used by whalemen.
One who withdraws; one who takes back, or retracts.
See Verst.
A narrow lane or alley. [Scot.] Jamieson.The narrow wynds, or alleys, on each side of the street. Bryant.
imp. & p. p. of Weep.
Worse. [Obs.]They say the world is much warre than it wont. Spenser.
One who manufactures articles from wire.
A whirligig.
The serum, or watery part, of milk, separated from the morethick or coagulable part, esp. in the process of making cheese. Inthis process, the thick part is called curd, and the thin part whey.
See Weasand. [Obs.]
A basket used in offices, libraries, etc., as a receptacle forwaste paper.
pl. pres. of Wit. Chaucer.
The dingo.
A kind of hard-twisted or braided cord, sometimes used formaking whiplashes.
Whitewashed or plastered with lime. "White-limed walls." Shak.
Somewhat weazen; shriveled. [Colloq.] "Weazeny, baked pears."Lowell.
Painting executed in size or distemper, on canvas or walls, --formerly, frequently taking the place of tapestry. Shak. Fairholt.
The American hawk owl. See under Hawk.
Vars of Wikiup.
The American merganser; -- called also weaser sheldrake.[Local, U. S.]
To take another turn with, as a cable around a windlass.Totten.
Woke. Chaucer.

The legal declaration of a person's mind as to the manner inwhich he would have his property or estate disposed of after hisdeath; the written instrument, legally executed, by which a man makesdisposition of his estate, to take effect after his death; testament;devise. See the Note under Testament, 1.
One who wenches; a lewd man.
Respecting words; full of words; wordy. [R.] Sir P. Sidney.-- Word"ish*ness, n.The truth they hide by their dark woordishness. Sir K. Digby.
The act of waving; a wavelike motion; a waft. R. Browning.An angry wafture of your hand. Shak.
Wicked. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A hydrous phosphate of alumina, occurring usually inhemispherical radiated forms varying in color from white to yellow,green, or black.
Won. Chaucer.
Away. [Obs. or Archaic] Chaucer. To do way, to take away; toremove. [Obs.] "Do way your hands." Chaucer.-- To make way with, to make away with. See under Away. [Archaic]
The pied wagtail. [Prov. Eng.]
To cause to become wanton; also, to waste in wantonness. [Obs.]
Linsey-woolsey.
Washy; weak. [Obs.]Their bodies of so weak and wash a temper. Beau. & Fl.

Sale of goods by the piece or large quantity, as distinguishedfrom retail. By wholesale, in the mass; in large quantities; withoutdistinction or discrimination.Some, from vanity or envy, despise a valuable book, and throwcontempt upon it by wholesale. I. Watts.
Capable of being washed without damage to fabric or color.
Any one of certain lines of a vessel, model, or plan, parallelwith the surface of the water at various heights from the keel.
See under Starwort.
A woman who performs any work; especially, a woman skilled inneedlework.
Of or pertaining to wolframium. See Tungstic.
a. & n. from Wring, v. Wringing machine, a wringer. SeeWringer, 2.

Any one of numerous species of snout beetles, or Rhynchophora,in which the head is elongated and usually curved downward. Many ofthe species are very injurious to cultivated plants. The larvæ ofsome of the species live in nuts, fruit, and grain by eating out theinterior, as the plum weevil, or curculio, the nut weevils, and thegrain weevil (see under Plum, Nut, and Grain). The larvæ of otherspecies bore under the bark and into the pith of trees and variousother plants, as the pine weevils (see under Pine). See also Peaweevil, Rice weevil, Seed weevil, under Pea, Rice, and Seed.
Prosperous; well. [Obs.] Wyclif.-- Wel"some*ly, adv. Wyclif.
In a whistling manner; shrilly.
The state of being a widower.
The water ousel.
Same as Wagonwright.
Any aquatic lizard of the genus Varanus, as the monitor of theNile. See Monitor, n., 3.
A weighing machine on which loaded carts may be weighed;platform scales.
Cast down; crushed by misery; dejected. [Obs.]
A perennial cruciferous herb (Nasturtium officinale) growingusually in clear running or spring water. The leaves are pungent, andused for salad and as an antiscorbutic.
Of or pertaining to Wesley or Wesleyanism.
See Wray. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a stable or garage, a place in the floor prepared so thatcarriages or automobiles may be washed there and the water run off.[Cant]
See Wanger. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having no wings; not able to ascend or fly. Wingless bird(Zoöl.), the apteryx.
One who, or that which, whines.
In a weak manner; with little strength or vigor; feebly.
To welk, or wither. [Obs.]

Any one numerous species of large marine gastropods belongingto Buccinum and allied genera; especially, Buccinum undatum, commonon the coasts both of Europe and North America, and much used as foodin Europe. Whelk tingle, a dog whelk. See under Dog.
The fruit of Trapa natans and Trapa bicornis, Old World waterplants bearing edible nutlike fruits armed with several hard andsharp points; also, the plant itself; -- called also water caltrop.
A piece of furniture holding the ewer or pitcher, basin, andother requisites for washing the person.
Incumbered with tall, woody hedgerows.
Any one of numerous species of small singing birds belonging toTroglodytes and numerous allied of the family Troglodytidæ.
The person to whom a warrant or warranty is made.
See Werewolf.
The American hornbeam. See Hornbeam.
See Wornil.
See Weasel.
Any gallinule.
A lantern wheel; a trundle.

Any one of several species of small curlews, especially theEuropean species (Numenius phæopus), called also Jack curlew, halfcurlew, stone curlew, and tang whaup. See Illustration in Appendix.Hudsonian or, Eskimo, whimbreal, the Hudsonian curlew.
To make water furrows in.

Act of one who wrestles; specif., the sport consisting of thehand-to-hand combat between two unarmed contestants who seek to throweach other. The various styles of wrestling differ in theirdefinition of a fall and in the governing rules. In Greco-Romanwrestling, tripping and taking hold of the legs are forbidden, and afall is gained (that is, the bout is won), by the contestant who pinsboth his opponent's shoulders to the ground. In catch-as-catch-canwrestling, all holds are permitted except such as may be barred bymutual consent, and a fall is defined as in Greco-Roman style.Lancashire style wrestling is essentially the same as catch-as-catch-can. In Cumberland and Westmorland wrestling the contestants standchest to chest, grasping each other around the body. The one firstlosing his hold, or touching the ground with any part of his bodyexcept his feet, loses the bout. If both fall to the ground at thesame time, it is a dogfall, and must be wrestled over. In theCornwall and Devon wrestling, the wrestlers complete in strong looselinen jackets, catching hold of the jacket, or anywhere above thewaist. Two shoulders and one hip, or two hips and one shoulder, musttouch the ground to constitute a fall, and if a man is thrownotherwise than on his back the contestants get upon their feet andthe bout recommences.
A forest officer appointed to walk over a certain space forinspection; a forester.
Tuberculosis, esp. of the lungs.
The sand martin, or bank swallow. [Prov. Eng.]
Having the color of the willow; resembling the willow; willowy.Walton.
One who weighs; specifically, an officer whose duty it is toweigh commodities.
A bird that feeds on wheat, especially the chaffinch.
The act or power of wielding. [Obs.] "Our weak wieldance." Bp.Hall.
A man who keeps ward; a guard. [R.] Sydney Smith.
One who worries.
In a waddling manner.
Polite; well-bred; complaisant; courteous. Dryden.
A plant growing in a state of nature; especially, one which hasrun wild, or escaped from cultivation.
A flood of water; an inundation.
imp. of Write. Wrote. Chaucer.
In a wrathy manner; very angrily; wrathfully. [Colloq.]
The edible fruit of two species of passion flower (Passifloralaurifolia, and P. maliformis); -- so called in the West Indies.
A whipstock.
To retire; to retreat; to quit a company or place; to go away;as, he withdrew from the company. "When the sea withdrew." King Horn.
A whitlow. [Obs.] Holland.
Womanhood. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The uterus. See Uterus.
Like winter; wintry; cold; hence, disagreeable, cheerless; as,winterly news. [R.] Shak.The sir growing more winterly in the month of April. Camden.
A throwing toy, or implement, of the Australian aborigines,consisting of a cigar-shaped stick fastened at one end to a flexibletwig. It weighs in all about two ounces, and is about two feet long.
A leguminous tree (Eperua falcata) of Demerara, with pinnateleaves and clusters of red flowers. The reddish brown wood is usedfor palings and shingles. J. Smith (Dict. Econ. Plants).
A rock shaft.
Thoroughly imbued with a right spirit; noble-minded; devoted.
The wych-elm. [Obs.] Bacon.
The person creating a wakf.
A wish of happiness. "A well-wish for his friends." Addison.
One who cheats at a horse race; one who bets, without a chanceof being able to pay; one who receives money to back certain horsesand absconds with it. [Written also welcher.] [Slang, Eng.]
Peevishness; ill temper; anger. [Obs.] Chaucer.
In a wild manner; without cultivation; with disorder; rudely;distractedly; extravagantly.
The day following Whitsunday; -- called also Whitsun Monday.
One who builds walls.
Something that whirls or turns about in a rapid manner; awhirligig.
The principles of the Whigs.
In a wandering manner.
The American snakebird. See Snakebird.
A dish consisting of small fish stewed and served in a littlewater. [Written also water souchet.] See Zoutch.
Having seen much; hence, accomplished; experienced. [Obs.]Beau. & Fl.Well-seen in arms and proved in many a fight. Spenser.
A solid of five sides, having a rectangular base, tworectangular or trapezoidal sides meeting in an edge, and twotriangular ends.
The quality of being wiry.
Wolfish. Shak.
Same as Whippletree.
A male witch; a wizard; a sprite; an imp. [Written alsowarluck.] Dryden.It was Eyvind Kallda's crew Of warlocks blue, With their caps ofdarkness hooded! Longfellow.
A climbing shrub (Tetracera alnifolia, or potatoria) of WesternAfrica, which pours out a watery sap from the freshly cut stems.

The quality or state of being wary; care to foresee and guardagainst evil; cautiousness. "An almost reptile wariness." G. W.Cable.To determine what are little things in religion, great wariness is tobe used. Sprat.

Any one of several species of Old World birds of the genusJynx, allied to the woodpeckers; especially, the common Europeanspecies (J. torguilla); -- so called from its habit of turning theneck around in different directions. Called also cuckoo's mate,snakebird, summer bird, tonguebird, and writheneck.

To think; to imagine; to fancy. [Obs. or Poetic] Spenser.Milton.I have lost more than thou wenest. Chaucer.For well I ween, Never before in the bowers of light Had the form ofan earthly fay been seen. J. R. Drake.Though never a dream the roses sent Of science or love's compliment,I ween they smelt as sweet. Mrs. Browning.
the reason why. [Colloq.]
A word of uncertain signification, used only in the phrase witha wanion, apparently equivalent to with a vengeance, with a plague,or with misfortune. [Obs.] B. Jonson. Latimer.
Weak. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Wheresoever. [Obs.]
The act of waiving, or not insisting on, some right, claim, orprivilege.
A native of, or a dweller in, the West Indies.
To wake; to cease to sleep; to be awakened.Early, Turnus wakening with the light. Dryden.

To move to and fro with a quick, jerking motion; to bendrapidly, or with a wavering motion, from side to side; to wag; tosquirm; to wriggle; as, the dog wiggles his tail; the tadpole wigglesin the water. [Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U. S.]
See Whaap. [Prov. Eng.]
Inclined to much writing; -- correlative to talkative. [R.]Pope.
Wisdom. [Obs.] Spenser.
Admitting of being easily wielded or managed. [Obs.] Golding.
A soft tumor or synovial swelling on the fetlock joint of ahorse; -- so called from having formerly been supposed to containair.

A piece generally projecting from a rotating or swinging piece,as an axle or rock shaft, for the purpose of raising stampers,lifting rods, or the like, and leaving them to fall by their ownweight; a kind of cam.
To ween. [Obs.] Chaucer.

To coved over in the season of winter, as for protection orshelter; as, to winter-ground the roods of a plant.The ruddock would . . . bring thee all this, Yea, and furred mossbesides, when flowers are none To winter-ground thy corse. Shak.
A place where wood is stored.

An intoxicating liquor distilled from grain, potatoes, etc.,especially in Scotland, Ireland, and the United States. In the UnitedStates, whisky is generally distilled from maize, rye, or wheat, butin Scotland and Ireland it is often made from malted barley. Bourbonwhisky, corn whisky made in Bourbon County, Kentucky.-- Crooked whisky. See under Crooked.-- Whisky Jack (Zoöl.), the Canada jay (Perisoreus Canadensis). Itis noted for its fearless and familiar habits when it frequents thecamps of lumbermen in the winter season. Its color is dull grayishblue, lighter beneath. Called also moose bird.
Becoming or life; of or pertaining to a wife. "Wifelypatience." Chaucer.With all the tenderness of wifely love. Dryden.
Oozy; wet. [Obs.] Drayton.
Blown down by the wind.
A Slavic tribe which once occupied the northern and easternparts of Germany, of which a small remnant exists.
The quality or state of being womanly.There is nothing wherein their womanliness is more honestly garnishedthan with silence. Udall.
Beaten or harassed by the severe weather of winter. Spenser.
The performer of any work; a master workman. [R.] Spenser.
An American aquatic plant (Dianthera Americana) with longwillowlike leaves, and spikes of small purplish flowers.
A disease of wheat and other grasses caused by the rust fungusPuccinia graminis; also, the fungus itself.
A large, hard pear, chiefly used for baking and roasting.[Obs.]I would have had him roasted like a warden. Beau. & Fl.Warden pie, a pie made of warden pears. [Obs.] Shak.
The European buffalo.
One who travels; a traveler; a passenger.
A large, open-headed cask, set up on end, to contain water.Dickens.
See Wave. Sir H. Wotton. Burke.
Having the anterior limbs or hands adapted for flight, as thebats and pterodactyls.
A whimsey.
See Weevil.
Having wheels; -- used chiefly in composition; as, a four-wheeled carriage.
A whirlpool. [Obs.] "Raging whirlpits." Sandys.
To wear. See 3d Wear. [Obs.] Chaucer.
a. & n. from Wade, v. Wading bird. (Zoöl.) See Wader, 2.
The constellation Aquarius.
Capable of being worked, or worth working; as, a workable mine;workable clay.

A perennial herb (Epilobium spicatum) with narrow willowlikeleaves and showy rose-purple flowers. The name is sometimes made toinclude other species of the same genus. Spiked willow-herb, aperennial herb (Lythrum Salicaria) with willowy leaves and spikedpurplish flowers.
Wary; watchful; cautious. [Obs.]
Out of which. [R.]The cleft whereout the lightning breaketh. Holland.
The wych-elm; -- so called because its leaves are like those ofthe hazel.
An exhibition of arms. according to the rank of the individual,by all persons bearing arms; -- formerly made at certain seasons ineach district. [Scot.] Jamieson. Sir W. Scott.
A pipe for conveying water.
A room for retirement from another room, as from a dining room;a drawing-room.A door in the middle leading to a parlor and withdrawing-room. Sir W.Scott.
A woman put out of the protection of the law. See Waive, v. t.,3 (b), and the Note.
To sail or pass to the windward of; as, to weather a cape; toweather another ship.
Same as Withe, n., 4.
One of two walls built on either side of the junction of abridge with the bank of a river, to protect the abutment of thebridge and the bank from the action of the current.
Struck with wonder, admiration, or surprise. Dryden.
Beset or overwhelmed with woe; immersed in grief or sorrow;woeful. Chaucer.So woe-begone was he with pains of love. Fairfax.
A weaver; originally, a female weaver. [Obs.] Brathwait.
Any one of various species of moths whose gregarious larvæ eatthe leaves of trees, and construct a large web to which they retreatwhen not feeding.
See White-face.
A speaker. [Obs.] Withlock.
Doing wonders or surprising things.
See Wroth. [Obs.]
A lock, as on a canal, in which boats are weighed and theirtonnage is settled.

Any one of several species of small Old World singing of thegenus Zosterops, as Zosterops palpebrosus of India, and Z.coerulescens of Australia. The eyes are encircled by a ring of whitefeathers, whence the name. Called also bush creeper, and white-eyedtit.
The act of wandering, or roaming. [Obs.] Bp. Hall.
An open car or chariot. [Obs.]Of old time coaches were not known in this island, but chariots, orwhirlicotes. Stow.
The canvasback.
Having a wick; -- used chiefly in composition; as, a two-wickedlamp.
One who makes ar a trade or business; a mercenary. [R.]Spenser.
The hunting of whales.
See Water moccasin.
Sorrow or sadness over the present or future evils or woes ofthe world in general; sentimental pessimism.
Same as Whitlow grass, under Whitlow.
Having weevils; weeviled. [Written also weevilly.]

Any one of several species of small birds of the genus Ampelis,in which some of the secondary quills are usually tipped with smallhorny ornaments resembling red sealing wax. The Bohemian waxwing (seeunder Bohemian) and the cedar bird are examples. Called also waxbird.

Full of watch; vigilant; attentive; careful to observe closely;observant; cautious; -- with of before the thing to be regulated orguarded; as, to be watchful of one's behavior; and with againstbefore the thing to be avoided; as, to be watchful against the growthof vicious habits. "Many a watchful night." Shak. "Happy watchfulshepherds." Milton.'Twixt prayer and watchful love his heart dividing. Keble.
The small pig of a litter. [Local, U. S.]
The act of washing cloth, dipping it in dye, etc., with awince. Wincing machine. (a) A wince. Ure. (b) A succession of winces.See Wince. Knight.
The American coot.
Swiftly; nimbly; quickly. [Obs.]
A helmeted Australian cockatoo (Calyptorhynchus funereus); --called also funeral cockatoo.
A table for holding working materials and implements; esp., asmall table with drawers and other conveniences for needlework, etc.
Capable of being plowed or cultivated; arable; tillable. [Obs.]Cowell.
Caused to ride or drive by the wind in opposition to the courseof the tide; -- said of a vessel lying at anchor, with wind and tideopposed to each other. Totten.
Of, pertaining to, or like, a wife or a woman. " Wifelikegovernment." Shak.
The system of doctrines and church polity inculcated by JohnWesley (b. 1703; d. 1791), the founder of the religious sect calledMethodist; Methodism. See Methodist, n., 2.
Work made of wood; that part of any structure which is wroughtof wood.
See Waft, n., 4.
The capybara.
Act of winding up, or closing; a concluding act or part; theend.
Emotion of desire; inclination; velleity. [Obs.] Hammond.
A blossom or plant of any species of the genus Nymphæa,distinguished for its large floating leaves and beautiful flowers.See Nymphæa.
Wretched. [Obs.] Wyclif.

Heavy plank or timber extending fore and aft the whole lengthof a vessel's deck at the line of junction with the sides, forming achannel to the scuppers, which are cut through it. In iron vesselsthe waterway is variously constructed.
A willow. See Willow, n., 2.
A sand snake (Charina plumbea) of Western North America, of thefamily Erycidæ.
Dizzy; giddy. [Prov. Eng.]

Full of wrath; angry; incensed; much exasperated; wrathful."Wroth to see his kingdom fail." Milton.Revel and truth as in a low degree, They be full wroth [i. e., atenmity] all day. Chaucer.Cain was very wroth, and his countenance fell. Gen. iv. 5.
Shaken by the wind; specif. (Forestry),
The young of the great black-backed gull (Larus marinus),formerly considered a distinct species. [Prov. Eng.]

Designating, or pertaining to, a kind of glass inclosure forkeeping ferns, mosses, etc., or for transporting growing plants froma distance; as, a Wardian case of plants; -- so named from theinventor, Nathaniel B. Ward, an Englishman.
Any plant of the genus Arum, especially, in England, thecuckoopint (Arum maculatum).
Discovered or described by Olanus Wormius, a Danish anatomist.Wormian bones, small irregular plates of bone often interposed in thesutures between the large cranial bones.
Any one of numerous species of small aquatic Entomostracabelonging to the genera Cyclops, Daphnia, etc; -- so called becausethey swim with sudden leaps, or starts.
Government by Whigs. [Cont] Swift.
Quality or state of being weakish.
Willingness; desire. [Obs.]

The point or side from which the wind blows; as, to ply to thewindward; -- opposed to Ant: leeward. To lay an anchor to thewindward, a figurative expression, signifying to adopt precautionaryor anticipatory measures for success or security.
Week. [Obs.] Chaucer.
The quality or state of being willing; free choice or consentof the will; freedom from reluctance; readiness of the mind to do orforbear.Sweet is the love which comes with willingness. Dryden.
To pass, or to draw off, (as steam) through narrow ports, orthe like, thus reducing its pressure or force by friction.
An Australian insessorial bird (Corcorax melanorhamphus) notedfor the curious actions of the male during the breeding season. It isblack with a white patch on each wing.
A widgeon. [R.]
A boomerang.
The osprey.
The first and third persons singular of the verb be, in theindicative mood, preterit (imperfect) tense; as, I was; he was.
One who, or that which, waters.
One who raises sheep for the production of wool.-- Wool"grow`ing, n.
See Welsh. [R.]

a. & n. from Whisper. v. t. Whispering gallery, or Whisperingdome, one of such a form that sounds produced in certain parts of itare concentrated by reflection from the walls to another part, sothat whispers or feeble sounds are audible at a much greater distancethan under ordinary circumstances.
In a wavering manner.
To wind, or wrap; especially, to wind a rope round, as a mastor yard made of two or more pieces, at the place where it has beenfished or scarfed, in order to strengthen it.
Having the character of a whoremaster; lecherous; libidinous.
Liable to roll over; crank; as, a walty ship. [R.] Longfellow.

A chamber surrounding a vessel or tube in which water may becirculated, thereby regulating the temperature or supply of heat tothe vessel. Used in laboratory and manufacturing equipment. water-jacketed. Having a water jacket; -- as, a water-jacketed condenser.
See under Gas.
Inclined to wabble; wabbling.

To move staggeringly or unsteadily from one side to the other;to vacillate; to move the manner of a rotating disk when the axis ofrotation is inclined to that of the disk; -- said of a turning orwhirling body; as, a top wabbles; a buzz saw wabbles. wobble.
At or in whatever place; wheresoever.He can not but love virtue wherever it is. Atterbury.
A saw for dividing timber lengthwise, usually set in a frame,and worked by two persons; also, a fret saw.

Any one of several species of wild and savage carnivoresbelonging to the genus Canis and closely allied to the common dog.The best-known and most destructive species are the European wolf(Canis lupus), the American gray, or timber, wolf (C. occidentalis),and the prairie wolf, or coyote. Wolves often hunt in packs, and maythus attack large animals and even man.
The wipe, or lapwing. [Prov. Eng.]
Worse. [Scot.]Murder and waur than number. Sir W. Scott.
Spread to a great distance; widely extended; extending far andwide; as, widespread wings; a widespread movement.
The quality or state of being wrong; wrongfulness; error;fault.The best great wrongnesses within themselves. Bp. Butler.The rightness or wrongness of this view. Latham.
See Wisp.
Same as Wartwort.
The process of treating silver ores by grinding in pans or tubswith the addition of mercury, and sometimes of chemicals such as bluevitriol and salt.
Wifeless. [Obs.] Homilies.
A tub in which clothes are washed.
So tight as to prevent the passing through of wind. Bp. Hall.
Without a woman or women.
A riding boot for men, the front of which came above the knee;also, a similar shorter boot worn under the trousers.
A particular method or pattern of weaving; as, the cassimereweave.
Work; a building. [Obs. or Scot.] Spenser.
Yarn made by the throstle, or water frame.
In a wan, or pale, manner.
The kittiwake. [Scot.]

A sort of pubescence, or a clothing of dense, curling hairs onthe surface of certain plants. Dead pulled wool, wool pulled from acarcass.-- Mineral wool. See under Mineral.-- Philosopher's wool. (Chem.) See Zinc oxide, under Zinc.-- Pulled wool, wool pulled from a pelt, or undressed hide.-- Slag wool. Same as Mineral wool, under Mineral.-- Wool ball, a ball or mass of wool.-- Wool burler, one who removes little burs, knots, or extraneousmatter, from wool, or the surface of woolen cloth.-- Wool comber. (a) One whose occupation is to comb wool. (b) Amachine for combing wool.-- Wool grass (Bot.), a kind of bulrush (Scirpus Eriophorum) withnumerous clustered woolly spikes.-- Wool scribbler. See Woolen scribbler, under Woolen, a.-- Wool sorter's disease (Med.), a disease, resembling malignantpustule, occurring among those who handle the wool of goats andsheep.-- Wool staple, a city or town where wool used to be brought to theking's staple for sale. [Eng.] -- Wool stapler. (a) One who deals inwool. (b) One who sorts wool according to its staple, or itsadaptation to different manufacturing purposes.-- Wool winder, a person employed to wind, or make up, wool intobundles to be packed for sale.
To cover. [Obs.]Wrie you in that mantle. Chaucer.
Wifely. [Obs.] Udall.
One engaged in the same work with another; a companion in work.
One who welcomes; one who salutes, or receives kindly, anewcomer. Shak.
A building at or within which goods, and the like, are weighed.

a & n. from Work.The word must cousin be to the working. Chaucer.Working beam. See Beam, n. 10.-- Working class, the class of people who are engaged in manuallabor, or are dependent upon it for support; laborers; operatives; --chiefly used in the plural.-- Working day. See under Day, n.-- Working drawing, a drawing, as of the whole or part of astructure, machine, etc., made to a scale, and intended to befollowed by the workmen. Working drawings are either general ordetail drawings.-- Working house, a house where work is performed; a workhouse.-- Working point (Mach.), that part of a machine at which the effectrequired; the point where the useful work is done.
Bugleweed.
Tending to wither; causing to shrink or fade.-- With"er*ing*ly, adv.
imp. of Wene. Chaucer.
Any aquatic bird; a water fowl.
A bundle of straw, or other material, to relieve the pressureof burdens carried upon the head. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
Being farthest to the windward.
The guelder-rose.
Tin ore freed from earthy matter by stamping. Knight.
To waive. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who waylays another.
A call by the boatswain's whistle.

The granting or dedication of property in trust for a piouspurpose, that is, to some object that tends to the good of mankind,as to support a mosque or caravansary, to provide for support ofone's family, kin, or neighbors, to benefit some particular person orpersons and afterward the poor, etc.; also, the trust so created, orthe property in trust.
A small, usually hard, tumor on the skin formed by enlargementof its vascular papillæ, and thickening of the epidermis which coversthem.
One who is pale, as from fear.
A nimble little fellow; a whippersnapper.Every puny whipster gets my sword. Shak.
One that taps, or cuts in on, telegraph wires and interceptsmessages; hence (Slang),
Unknowing; also, unknown; unmeaning. [Obs.] Spenser.

Any one of numerous species of aquatic beetles belonging toDytiscus and allied genera of the family Dytiscidæ, and to variousgenera of the family Hydrophilidæ. These beetles swim with greatagility, the fringed hind legs acting together like oars.
A plate heated by hot water contained in a double bottom orjacket. Knight.
Consumed, or rendered useless, by wearing; as, worn-outgarments.
A week day or working day, as distinguished from Sunday or aholiday. Also used adjectively. [Written also workiday, andworkaday.] [Obs. or Colloq.]Prithee, tell her but a workyday fortune. Shak.

Any one of various species of small carnivores belonging to thegenus Putorius, as the ermine and ferret. They have a slender,elongated body, and are noted for the quickness of their movementsand for their bloodthirsty habit in destroying poultry, rats, etc.The ermine and some other species are brown in summer, and turn whitein winter; others are brown at all seasons. Malacca weasel, therasse.-- Weasel coot, a female or young male of the smew; -- so calledfrom the resemblance of the head to that of a weasel. Called alsoweasel duck.-- Weasel lemur, a short-tailed lemur (Lepilemur mustelinus). It isreddish brown above, grayish brown below, with the throat white.
To reveal; to disclose. [Obs.]To no wight thou shalt this counsel wray. Chaucer.
A land full of wonders, or marvels. M. Arnold.
To whir. [Obs.]
Capable of being wielded; manageable; wieldable; -- opposed tounwieldy. [R.] Johnson.
Somewhat wan; of a pale hue.No sun, but a wannish glare, In fold upon fold of hueless cloud.Tennyson.
A kind of pleasure wagon, uncovered and with seats extendedalong the sides, designed to carry six or eight persons besides thedriver.

Any one of several species of edible marine fishes belonging tothe genus Trachinus, of the family Trachinidæ. They have a broadspinose head, with the eyes looking upward. The long dorsal fin issupported by numerous strong, sharp spines which cause painfulwounds.
Having performed wonders; able to perform wonderful things.[Obs.] Shak.

Of or pertaining to wassail, or to a wassail; convivial; as, awassail bowl. "Awassail candle, my lord, all tallow." Shak. Wassailbowl, a bowl in which wassail was mixed, and placed upon the table."Spiced wassail bowl." J. Fletcher. "When the cloth was removed, thebutler brought in a huge silver vessel . . . Its appearance washailed with acclamation, being the wassail bowl so renowned inChristmas festivity." W. Irving.-- Wassail cup, a cup from which wassail was drunk.
The agile, or silvery, gibbon; -- called also camper. SeeGibbon. [Written also wow-wow.]
To wail. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Madder.
A cell containing water; specifically (Zoöl.), one of the cellsor chambers in which water is stored up in the stomach of a camel.
Furnished with wattles, or pendent fleshy processes at the chinor throat.The wattled cocks strut to and fro. Longfellow.
One of a family of plants having pitcher-shaped leaves. Thesidesaddle flower (Sarracenia purpurea) is the type.
destitute of wine; as, wineless life.
The act of withholding.
Hard to steer; -- said of a vessel.

A person of the Caucasian race (6 Fed. Rep. 256). In the timeof slavery in the United States white person was generally construedas a person without admixture of colored blood. In various statutesand decisions in different States since 1865 white person isconstrued as in effect: one not having any negro blood (Ark., Okla.);one having less than one eighth of negro blood (Ala., Fla., Ga.,Ind., Ky., Md., Minn., Miss., Mo., N.C., S.C., Tenn., Tex.); onehaving less than one fourth (Mich., Neb., Ore., Va.); one having lessthan one half (Ohio).
Same as Wegotism.
Cloth made of wool; woollen goods.
' (as, a would-be poet.

Any one of several species of honey eaters belonging toAnthochæra and allied genera of the family Meliphagidæ. These birdsusually have a large and conspicuous wattle of naked skin hangingdown below each ear. They are natives of Australia and adjacentislands.
Having webbed feet; palmiped; as, a goose or a duck is a web-footed fowl.
Broad and truncate at the summit, and tapering down to thebase; as, a wedge-shaped leaf.
Wide. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A ravine through which a brook flows; the channel of a watercourse, which is dry except in the rainy season.
Somewhat weak; rather weak.
Something; thing; stuff. [Obs.]And gave him for to feed, Such homely what as serves the simpleSpenser.

A violent and peremptory procedure without any assigned reason;a sudden conclusive happening. [Obs.]When the church Was taken with a why-not in the lurch. Hudibras.This game . . . was like to have been lost with a why-not. NugæAntiq.
A kind of waved or watered tabby. See Tabby, n., 1.
Same as Withvine.
A small lathe for turning wooden pins.
Quitch grass.
The moosewood, or striped maple. See Maple.
A North American shrub (Viburnum nudum) whose tough osierlikeshoots are sometimes used for binding sheaves.
A tower in which a sentinel is placed to watch for enemies, theapproach of danger, or the like.
Attracting; adapted to gain favor; charming; as, a winningaddress. "Each mild and winning note." Keble.
The quality of being worldly; a predominant passion forobtaining the good things of this life; covetousness; addictedness togain and temporal enjoyments; worldly-mindedness.
Undulating on the border or surface; waved.
Having sides nearly perpendicular; -- said of certain vesselsto distinguish them from those having flaring sides, or sidestumbling home (see under Tumble, v. i.).
The rod or handle to which the lash of a whip is fastened.
Same as Ordeal by water. See the Note under Ordeal, n., 1.
A finding of carriages, carts, etc., for the transportation ofgoods, produce, etc. Ainsworth.
The gnu.
The lapwing. [Prov. Eng.]
The wych-elm.(b) An American shrub or small tree (Hamamelis Virginica), whichblossoms late in autumn.
Worse. [R.]Thou dost deserve a worser end. Beau. & Fl.From worser thoughts which make me do amiss. Bunyan.A dreadful quiet felt, and, worser far Than arms, a sullen intervalof war. Dryden.
To wrestle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Colloq. U.S.]Who wrastleth best naked, with oil enoint. Chaucer.

Without any power (cf. Watt); -- said of an alternating currentor component of current when it differs in phase by ninety degreesfrom the electromotive force which produces it, or of anelectromotive force or component thereof when the current it producesdiffers from it in phase by 90 degrees.
Capacious. [Obs.] Shak.
To behave wantonly; to frolic; to wanton. [R.] Lamb.
The yaffle.

One who assures, or covenants to assure; one who contracts tosecure another in a right, or to make good any defect of title orquality; one who gives a warranty; a guarantor; as, the warranter ofa horse.
A place where grapes are converted into wine.
To rot by steeping in water; to water-ret; as, to water-rothemp or flax.
The ridge between the shoulder bones of a horse, at the base ofthe neck. See Illust. of Horse.Let the galled jade wince; our withers are unwrung. Shak.
See Wood worm, under Wood.
One given to whims; hence, a weak, childish person; a child.Go, whimling, and fetch two or three grating loaves. Beau. & Fl.
Ill-tempered. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Evil or wicked behavior or action.
A kind of fine sand from the banks of the Trent, used as apolishing powder. [Eng.]
The fourth day of the week; the next day after Tuesday. AshWednesday. See in the Vocabulary.

A molding, or other projection, in the wall of a building, tothrow off the water, -- generally used in the United States for thefirst table above the surface of the ground (see Table, n., 9), thatis, for the table at the top of the foundation and the beginning ofthe upper wall.
A deep furrow for conducting water from the ground, and keepingthe surface soil dry.
Quality of being warlike.
Wet; moist; marshy. [Obs.]
The middle subdivision of the Upper Silurian in Great Britain;-- so named from the typical locality in Shropshire.
The act of one who winces.
A surcingle, or strap of leather, used for binding a load uponthe back of a beast; also, a leather tie; a short wagon rope. [Prov.Eng.]
Want of hope; despair; also, faint or delusive hope; delusion.[Obs.] Piers Plowman. "Wanhope and distress." Chaucer.
a. & n. from Wish, v. t. Wishing bone. See Wishbone.-- Wishing cap, a cap fabled to give one whatever he wishes for whenwearing it.

Any one of several species of fresh-water ducks, especiallythose belonging to the subgenus Mareca, of the genus Anas. The commonEuropean widgeon (Anas penelope) and the American widgeon (A.Americana) are the most important species. The latter is called alsobaldhead, baldpate, baldface, baldcrown, smoking duck, wheat, duck,and whitebelly. Bald-faced, or Green-headed, widgeon, the Americanwidgeon.-- Black widgeon, the European tufted duck.-- Gray widgeon. (a) The gadwall. (b) The pintail duck.-- Great headed widgeon, the poachard.-- Pied widgeon. (a) The poachard. (b) The goosander. Saw-billedwidgeon, the merganser.-- Sea widgeon. See in the Vocabulary.-- Spear widgeon, the goosander. [Prov. Eng.] -- Spoonbilledwidgeon, the shoveler.-- White widgeon, the smew.-- Wood widgeon, the wood duck.
A hydrous sulphate of alumina occurring in white reniformmasses.
Wheresoever. [Obs.] Chaucer.
To whine. [Scot.] Burns.
An elastic band worn around the wrist, as for the purpose ofsecuring the upper part of a glove.
The king parrakeet See under King.
A man employed in the whale fishery.
Tending towards lower prices; as, a weak market.
Done at an improper time; ill-timed.
A dance performed by two persons in circular figures with awhirling motion; also, a piece of music composed in triple measurefor this kind of dance.
A European poisonous umbelliferous plant (Enanthe fistulosa)with large hollow stems and finely divided leaves.
To cause to decrease. [Obs.] B. Jonson.
Destitute of a window. Carlyle.
An East Indian plant (Kæmpferia Galanga) of the Ginger family.See Galanga.
Not using words; not speaking; silent; speechless. Shak.

A kind of knot often used at the end of a rope; a wall knot; awale. Wall knot, a knot made by unlaying the strands of a rope, andmaking a bight with the first strand, then passing the second overthe end of the first, and the third over the end of the second andthrough the bight of the first; a wale knot. Wall knots may be singleor double, crowned or double-crowned.
A compound of iron, such as puddled steel, made withoutcomplete fusion.
Resembling a whore in character or conduct; addicted tounlawful pleasures; incontinent; lewd; unchaste.-- Whor"ish*ly, adv.-- Whor"ish*ness, n.
Worn by the waves.The shore that o'er his wave-worn basis bowed. Shak.
Loathsome; disgusting; hateful. [Obs.]Murder is . . . wlatsom and abhominable to God. Chaucer.
Excessive. [Obs.]Such a world of holidays, that 't a woundy hindrance to a poor manthat lives by his labor. L'Estrange.
Of or pertaining to the Waldenses.-- n.
p. p. of Write, v.

To perform acts of homage or adoration; esp., to performreligious service.Our fathers worshiped in this mountain; and ye say that in Jerusalemis the place where men ought to worship. John iv. 20.Was it for this I have loved . . . and worshiped in silenceLongfellow.
A species of elm (Ulmus montana) found in Northern and WesternEurope; Scotch elm.
Having strong affection; cordial; sincere; hearty; sympathetic.-- Warm"-heart`ed*ness, n.

The bank of a river, or the shore of the sea. [Obs.] "The fatweed that roots itself in ease on Lethe wharf." Shak. Wharf boat, akind of boat moored at the bank of a river, and used for a wharf, inplaces where the height of the water is so variable that a fixedwharf would be useless. [U. S.] Bartlett.-- Wharf rat. (Zoöl.) (a) The common brown rat. (b) A neglected boywho lives around the wharfs. [Slang]
That may be wearied.
One who holds by a wadset.
3d pers. sing. pres. of Write, for writeth. Chaucer.
An aquatic European plant (Stratiotes aloides) with bayonet-shaped leaves.
A kind of coarse grass growing in wet grounds, and supposed tobe injurious to sheep. [Prov. Eng.]
Any one of numerous species of water; the skater. See Skater,n., 2.
The hippopotamus. [R.]
The quality or state of being whitish or somewhat white.
In water-color painting, work in, or a work done chiefly in,washes, as distinguished from that done in stipple, in body color,etc.
The quality or state of being woolly.
Same as Tungsten steel.
To graft by cutting the scion and stock in a certain manner.See Whip grafting, under Grafting.

To move one way and the other with quick turns; to shake to andfro; to move vibratingly; to cause to vibrate, as a part of the body;as, to wag the head.No discerner durst wag his tongue in censure. Shak.Every one that passeth thereby shall be astonished, and wag his head.Jer. xviii. 16.
See Wariangle. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
To whinny. [Colloq.]
One who makes widows by destroying husbands. [R.] Shak.
Wise. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A publication issued once in seven days, or appearing once aweek.
One of the longitudinal ribs or ridges on the barrel of acapstan or a windless; -- usually in the plural; as, the whelps of awindlass.
A woman who practices unlawful sexual commerce with men,especially one who prostitutes her body for hire; a prostitute; aharlot. Wyclif.
Hot. [Obs.] Spenser.
Situated the farthest towards the west; most western.
An American shrub (Symphoricarpus occidentalis) which bearssoft white berries.
A widow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Eaten into, defaced, or worn, by exposure to the weather.Coleridge.
A contrivance for measuring a supply of water delivered orreceived for any purpose, as from a street main.
The common American eider.
A negro. [Low]
To break the wind of; to cause to lose breath; to exhaust. [R.]'T would wind-break a mule to vie burdens with her. Ford.
A striped variety of hornstone, resembling wood in appearance.
A wonderful work or act; a prodigy; a miracle.Such as in strange land He found in wonderworks of God and Nature'shand. Byron.
In the old German empire, the head forest keeper.
A genus of ferns, one species of which (Woodwardia radicans) isa showy plant in California, the Azores, etc.
A small annual plant (Montia fontana) growing in wet places insouthern regions.
Full of weeping or lamentation; grieving. [Obs.] Wyclif.

To become weak or weaker; to lose strength, spirit, ordetermination; to become less positive or resolute; as, the patientweakened; the witness weakened on cross-examination. "His notionweakens, his discernings are lethargied." Shak.

A large monkey (Macacus silenus) native of Malabar. It isblack, or nearly so, but has a long white or gray beard encirclingthe face. Called also maha, silenus, neelbhunder, lion-tailed baboon,and great wanderoo. [Written also ouanderoo.]
Twisted; made into a wreath. "Wreathen work of pure gold." Ex.xxviii. 22.
Of or pertaining to the woods or forest. [Colloq. U. S.]It [sugar making] is woodsy, and savors of trees. J. Burroughs.
In a weighty manner.
Having an eye of a very light gray or whitish color. Booth.
See Yapock, and the Note under Opossum.
A variant of 1st Wick.
A variety of winter apple of medium size, deep red color, andyellowish flesh of a rich, rather subacid flavor.
An indolent, encysted tumor of the skin; especially, asebaceous cyst.
A kind of mustard (Sinapis alba) with rough-hairy foliage, along-beaked hispid pod, and pale seeds, which yield mustard andmustard oil. The plant is also grown for forage.
Without. [Obs.] Chaucer.
An overfall, or weir, for the escape, or overflow, ofsuperfluous water from a canal, reservoir, pond, or the like.
Somewhat wet; moist; humid.

To cry with a low, whining, broken voice; to whine; tocomplain; as, a child whimpers.Was there ever yet preacher but there were gainsayers that spurned,that winced, that whimpered against him Latimer.
To damage, impair, or injure, as an estate, voluntarily, or bysuffering the buildings, fences, etc., to go to decay.
The Virginia deer.
From, or forth from, what or which place; whence. [Obs.]Spenser.
In a warm manner; ardently.

A large gallinule (Gallicrex cristatus) native of Australia,India, and the East Indies. In the breeding season the male is blackand has a fleshy red caruncle, or horn, on the top of its head.Called also kora.
A witling. [R.] Milton.
Failing or diminishing trust; want of trust or confidence;distrust. [Obs.] Chaucer.

Having warm blood; -- applied especially to those animals, asbirds and mammals, which have warm blood, or, more properly, thepower of maintaining a nearly uniform temperature whatever thetemperature of the surrounding air. See Homoiothermal.

Any one of several species of Old World warblers, esp. thecommon European species (Sylvia cinerea), called also strawsmear,nettlebird, muff, and whitecap, the garden whitethroat, or goldenwarbler (S. hortensis), and the lesser whitethroat (S. curruca).
The common American gallinule.
A light color of the iris in horses; wall-eye. [Written alsowhaul.]
See Water table.
A silicate of zinc, usually occurring massive and of a greenishyellow color, also in reddish crystals (troostite) containingmanganese.
Any one of numerous small injurious hemipterous insects of thegenus Aleyrodes, allied to scale insects. They are usually coveredwith a white or gray powder.
One who, or that which, weakens. "[Fastings] weakeners of sin."South.
The common cat-tail (Typha latifolia), the spike of which makesa good torch soaked in oil. Dr. Prior.
Winsome. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Shaped like a worm; as, a worm-shaped root.
To extract, as ore or coal. Raymond.
See Nepa.
See Welaway. [Obs.]
The red-backed shrike (Lanius collurio); -- called also würger,worrier, and throttler. [Written also warriangle, weirangle, etc.][Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
A rectangular rent made in cloth; -- called also winkle-hole.[Local, U. S.] Bartlett.

The plural nominative case of the pronoun of the first person;the word with which a person in speaking or writing denotes a numberor company of which he is one, as the subject of an action expressedby a verb.
imp. of Weep.

Traveling; passing; being on a journey. "A wayfaring man."Judg. xix. 17. Wayfaring tree (Bot.), a European shrub (Viburnumlantana) having large ovate leaves and dense cymes of small whiteflowers.-- American wayfaring tree (Bot.), the (Viburnum lantanoides).
Same as Wash sale.
Any plant of the genus Phytocrene, climbing shrubs of Asia andAfrica, the stems of which are singularly porous, and when cut streamwith a limpid potable juice.
The act of withdrawing; withdrawment; retreat; retraction.Fielding.
A pile of salted fish heaped up to drain.
Whosoever. Piers Plowman.Whoso shrinks or falters now, . . . Brand the craven on his brow!Whittier.
The action of the elements on a rock in altering its color,texture, or composition, or in rounding off its edges.

Of or pertaining to A. G. Werner, The German mineralogist andgeologist, who classified minerals according to their externalcharacters, and advocated the theory that the strata of the earth'scrust were formed by depositions from water; designating, oraccording to, Werner's system.
Having elongated hairs, feathers, or bristles on the cheeks.The whiskered vermin race. Grainger.
To whirl; to eddy. [R.]The waters went wirbling above and around. Owen. Meredith.
Wrong in opinion or principle; having a perverse understanding;perverse.-- Wrong"head`ed*ly, adv.-- Wrong"head`ed*ness, n. Macaulay.
= Wire-wound gun.
To drain, as land; by means of wells, or pits, which receivethe water, and from which it is discharged by machinery.
A small yelping cur. [Prov. Eng.]
One who withholds.
See Anacharis.
Kept in port or at anchor by storms; delayed by bad weather;as, a weather-bound vessel.
A fluophosphate of magnesia, occurring in yellowish crystals,and also in massive forms.
Whatsoever; whosoever; whatever; anything that. [Obs.]Whatso he were, of high or low estate. Chaucer.Whatso the heaven in his wide vault contains. Spenser.
Faded; dried up; shriveled; wilted; wasted; wasted away.-- With"ered*ness, n. Bp. Hall.
Balanced or considered with reference to public weal. [Obs.]Shak.
See under Brash.

A station for taking meteorological observations, makingweather forecasts, or disseminating such information. Such stationsare of the first order when they make observations of all theimportant elements either hourly or by self-registering instruments;of the second order when only important observations are taken; ofthe third order when simpler work is done, as to record rainfall andmaximum and minimum temperatures.
One who works at a willying machine.
See Water hare.
One who wooes; one who courts or solicits in love; a suitor. "Athriving wooer." Gibber.
Of the nature of, or containing, whey; resembling whey;wheyish. Bacon.
One who wills.
A small white-flowered shrub; brookweed.
A liquid food composed of water and a small portion of meal, orother farinaceous substance, boiled and seasoned.
With a whizzing sound.
A water buck.
One who breaks jests; a joker. [Obs.] Shak.
Woeful; sorrowful. [Obs.]His clerk was woe to do that deed. Robert of Brunne.Woe was this knight and sorrowfully he sighed. Chaucer.And looking up he waxed wondrous woe. Spenser.
An officer of the forest, whose duty it was to guard the woods.
See under Wagtail.
See Wearish. [Obs.]
A wild or natural note, as of a forest bird. [R.]Or sweetest Shakespeare, fancy's child, Warble his native wood-noteswild. Milton.
A plant that grows in water; an aquatic plant.
Without a wife; unmarried. Chaucer.
A female waiter or attendant; a waiting maid or waiting woman.
The action of one who procures or holds a woman or women forunwilling prostitution.
To attack or beat with a waddy.
The leaves of Sarace. See Trumpets.
The wheatear.
The capybara.
The quality of being witty.
Any one of several species of long-billed limicoline birdsbelonging to the genera Scolopax and Philohela. They are mostlynocturnal in their habits, and are highly esteemed as game birds.
See Will I, nill I, etc., under 3d Will.
A kind of mattress made of, or covered with, waterproof fabricand filled with water. It is used in hospitals for bedriddenpatients.

Any one of numerous species of finchlike birds belonging toEstrelda and allied genera, native of Asia, Africa, and Australia.The bill is large, conical, and usually red in color, resemblingsealing wax. Several of the species are often kept as cage birds.
Same as Vermes.
One who wishes or desires; one who expresses a wish. Shak.
In a winning manner.
A source, spring, or fountain.At the wellhead the purest streams arise. Spenser.Our public-school and university life is a great wellhead of new andirresponsible words. Earle.
Whipped.
To root with the snout. See 1st Root. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Having no wart.
Clumsily; stupidly; blockishly. R. North.
A shop where any manufacture or handiwork is carried on.
Same as Wagonful.
Having undulations like waves; -- said of one of the lines inheraldry which serve as outlines to the ordinaries, etc.
The second person singular of the verb be, in the indicativemood, imperfect tense; -- now used only in solemn or poetical style.See Was.
A shallow drinking bowl. [Prov. Eng.] Ray.
The common dooryard plantain (Plantago major).
