Like a wolf; having the qualities or form of a wolf; as, awolfish visage; wolfish designs.-- Wolf"ish*ly, adv.-- Wolf"ish*ness, n.
The hoopoe.
Any long-legged bird that wades in the water in search of food,especially any species of limicoline or grallatorial birds; -- calledalso wading bird. See Illust. g, under Aves.
A room occupied as a messroom by the commissioned officers of awar vessel. See Gunroom. Totten.
One who performs wonders, or miracles.
The American black-tailed godwit.
The edible tuber of a species of arrowhead (Sagittariavariabilis); -- so called by the Indians of Oregon. [Written alsowappato.]

The resistance against which a machine acts, as opposed to thepower which moves it. [Obs.] Atomic weight. (Chem.) See under Atomic,and cf. Element.-- Dead weight, Feather weight, Heavy weight, Light weight, etc. Seeunder Dead, Feather, etc.-- Weight of observation (Astron. & Physics), a number expressingthe most probable relative value of each observation in determiningthe result of a series of observations of the same kind.
The pied wagtail; -- so called in allusion to its beating thewater with its tail while tripping along the leaves of water plants.[Prov. Eng.]

A provincial name given in England to basaltic rocks, andapplied by miners to other kind of dark-colored unstratified rockswhich resist the point of the pick.-- for example, to masses of chert. Whin-dikes, and whin-sills, arenames sometimes given to veins or beds of basalt.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling the style of, Richard Wagner,the German musical composer.
Made sloping, so as to throw off water; as, a weathered corniceor window sill.
To worry; to annoy. [Illiterate]
In wool; with woolen raiment next the skin. [Obs.]
The wryneck; -- so called from its cry. [Prov. Eng.]
A weaver bird.
Having a shriveled, thin, withered face.
Resembling or becoming a wizard; wizardlike; weird.
A kind of food made of milk or cream, eggs, sugar, bread, etc.,baked in a pot. King.
Lit., wise men; specif. (A.-S. Hist.),
Any one of numerous species of scansorial birds belonging toPicus and many allied genera of the family Picidæ.
To signal by means of a flag waved from side to side accordingto a code adopted for the purpose. [Colloq.]
Of or pertaining to the west; toward the west; coming from thewest; western.
A bolt used by shipwrights, to bend and secure the planksagainst the timbers till they are fastened by bolts, spikes, ortreenails; -- not to be confounded with ringbolt.
Surprise; astonishment; a wonderful appearance; a wonder.Bacon.All the common sights they view, Their wonderment engage. Sir W.Scott.
Made of, or covered with, twigs or osiers, or wickerwork.Each one a little wicker basket had, Made of fine twigs, entrailédcuriously. Spenser.
See Welsher.
Having the iris of light color; -- said of horses. "Whallyeyes." Spenser.
A diminutive, insignificant, or presumptuous person. [Colloq.]"Little whippersnappers like you." T. Hughes.
Hautboys, or oboes, played by town musicians; not used in thesingular. [Obs.] Halliwell.
A spendthrift. [Obs.]
Having whelks; whelky; as, whelked horns. Shak.
The barn owl. [Prov. Eng.] [Written also oolert, and owlerd.]
Furnished with whorls; arranged in the form of a whorl orwhorls; verticillate; as, whorled leaves.
A knife; esp., a pocket, sheath, or clasp knife. "A butcher'swhittle." Dryden. "Rude whittles." Macaulay.He wore a Sheffield whittle in his hose. Betterton.
As much as a wagon will hold; enough to fill a wagon; awagonload.
The state of being bewildered; confusion; bewilderment.And snatched her breathless from beneath This wilderment of wreck anddeath. Moore.
The quality of being weatherly.
One who worships; one who pays divine honors to any being orthing; one who adores. [Written also worshipper.]
A kind of speedwell (Veronica Anagallis) found in wet places inEurope and America.
See Waggel.
Goods which, after shipwreck, appear floating on the waves, orsea.
A woman who wails. [Obs.]
Having good success.
A temporary mark or boundary, as a bough of a tree set up inmarking out or dividing anything, as tithes, swaths to be mowed incommon ground, etc.; -- called also wicker. [Prov. Eng.]
A boat bug.
The principles or practices of the Whigs; Whiggism.
p. p. of Wax. Chaucer.
Working, or able to sail, close to the wind; as, a weatherlyship. Cooper.
Handsome; wellformed; beautiful; pleasing to the eye.Rachel was beautiful and well-favored. Gen. xxix. 17.
A pore by which the water tubes of various invertebrates openexternally.
A burrow made by a worm.
Circular; suitable to rotation.
Free from waves; undisturbed; not agitated; as, the wavelesssea.
A dangerous disease of sheep.
To turn over. [Prov. Eng.]
The abdomen; the uterus; the womb. [Obs.]
The necessary means or instrument.So shall I have wherewith to answer him. Ps. cxix. 42.The wherewith to meet excessive loss by radiation. H. Spencer.
A man whose occupation is to make or repair wheels and wheeledvehicles, as carts, wagons, and the like.

The space between the pillars, in postand-stall working.Raymond. Wicket door, Wicket gate, a small door or gate; a wicket.See def. 1, above. Bunyan.-- Wicket keeper (Cricket), the player who stands behind the wicketto catch the balls and endeavor to put the batsman out.
Woad. [Obs.]
An instrument or machine serving to measure time by the fall,or flow, of a certain quantity of water; a clepsydra.
To move irregularly or awkwardly; to wamble, or wabble. [Prov.Eng.]
Made of wheat; as, wheaten bread. Cowper.
To wither; to dry. [Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
A little or young wolf. Tennyson.
See Water buck.
The wax-covered fruit of the wax myrtle, or bayberry. SeeBayberry, and Candleberry tree.
Born of a noble or respect able family; not of mean birth.
Nuptial ceremony; nuptial festivities; marriage; nuptials.Simple and brief was the wedding, as that of Ruth and of Boaz.Longfellow.
The Chinese name of one or two species of bamboo, or jointedcane, of the genus Phyllostachys. The slender stems are much used forwalking sticks. [Written also whanghee.]
Same as Wringbolt.

Lying toward the west; situated at the west, or in a westerndirection from the point of observation or reckoning; proceedingtoward the west, or coming from the west; as, a west course is onetoward the west; an east and west line; a west wind blows from thewest.This shall be your west border. Num. xxxiv. 6.West end, the fashionable part of London, commencing from the east,at Charing Cross.

Well-doing or well-being in any respect; the enjoyment ofhealth and the common blessings of life; exemption from any evil orcalamity; prosperity; happiness.How to study for the people's welfare. Shak.In whose deep eyes Men read the welfare of the times to come.Emerson.

To move the body to and fro with short, writhing motions, likea worm; to squirm; to twist uneasily or quickly about.Both he and successors would often wriggle in their seats, as long asthe cushion lasted. Swift.
A fitting, usually having a plug, applied to a cistern, tub,sink, or the like, and forming the outlet opening.
One who, or that which, whooops. Woopher swan. (Zoöl.) See theNote under Swan.
Long and flexible, like a wand. [Prov. Eng.] Brockett.

The washing out or away of earth, etc., especially of a portionof the bed of a road or railroad by a fall of rain or a freshet;also, a place, especially in the bed of a road or railroad, where theearth has been washed away.
A poisonous plant (Aconitum Lycoctonum), a kind of monkshood;also, by extension, any plant or species of the genus Aconitum. SeeAconite.

The quality or state of being wanton; negligence of restraint;sportiveness; recklessness; lasciviousness. Gower.The tumults threatened to abuse all acts of grace, and turn them intowantonness. Eikon Basilike.Young gentlemen would be as sad as night Only for wantonness. Shak.
A name given to several plants because they were thought to bea cure for warts, as a kind of spurge (Euphorbia Helioscopia), andthe nipplewort (Lampsana communis).
A firm, elastic substance resembling horn, taken from the upperjaw of the right whale; baleen. It is used as a stiffening in stays,fans, screens, and for various other purposes. See Baleen.
To reel, sway, or move from side to side; to move with awagging motion; to waddle.Why do you go nodding and waggling so L'Estrange.

Any tree or shrub of the genus Salix, including many species,most of which are characterized often used as an emblem of sorrow,desolation, or desertion. "A wreath of willow to show my forsakenplight." Sir W. Scott. Hence, a lover forsaken by, or having lost,the person beloved, is said to wear the willow.And I must wear the willow garland For him that's dead or false tome. Campbell.
A friction gear wheel with wedge-shaped circumferentialgrooves. -- Wedge gearing.
In a wise manner; prudently; judiciously; discreetly; withwisdom.And wisely learn to curb thy sorrows wild. Milton.
The act of warping; also, a charge per ton made on shipping insome harbors.

Made, as a vowel, with a less tense, and more open and relaxed,condition of the mouth organs; -- opposed to primary as used by Mr.Bell, and to narrow as used by Mr. Sweet. The effect, as explained byMr. Bell, is due to the relaxation or tension of the pharynx; asexplained by Mr. Sweet and others, it is due to the action of thetongue. The wide of e (eve) is î (îll); of a (ate) is ê (ênd), etc.See Guide to Pronunciation, § 13-15.
The young, either larva or pupa, of the mosquito; -- calledalso wiggletail.
A tuyère kept cool by water circulating within a casing. It isused for hot blast.

A town in Berkshire, England. Windsor bean. (Bot.) See underBean.-- Windsor chair, a kind of strong, plain, polished, wooden chair.Simmonds.-- Windsor soap, a scented soap well known for its excellence.
A vessel or person employed in the whale fishery.
Becoming a skillful workman; skillful; well performed;workmanlike.

Any one of numerous edible, marine, spiny-finned fishes of thegenus Labrus, of which several species are found in the Mediterraneanand on the Atlantic coast of Europe. Many of the species are bright-colored.
Having no want; abundant; fruitful.
A rate or tax for a supply of water.
To contradict; to gainsay; to deny; to renounce. [Obs.] Gower.If that he his Christendom withsay. Chaucer.
A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
Water confined in specially constructed compartments in avessel's hold, to serve as ballast.
One who, or that which, warms.
Indian rice. See under Rice.
To whatever place; to what place soever; wheresoever; as, Iwill go whithersoever you lead.
A kind of coarse upper coat, or overcoat, formerly worn.
Having the fingers united by a web for a considerable part oftheir length.
Quality of being wooden; clumsiness; stupidity; blockishness.We set our faces against the woodenness which then characterizedGerman philology. Sweet.
One whose occupation is to make and repair watches.
A little wave; a ripple.
Warmth. Chaucer.
One who rides a bicycle or tricycle; a cycler, or cyclist.
Same as Curare.
A laboring man; a man who earns his daily support by manuallabor.
The possessive of whosoever. See Whosoever.
Worn by the action of wheels; as, a wheel-worn road.
An outbuilding for washing, esp. one for washing clothes; alaundry.
A whoremaster; a lecher; a man who frequents the society ofwhores.
A winding and circuitous way; a roundabout course; a shift.
The character or practices o "He acquired a reputationbordering on wizardry." J. A. Symonds.
A kind of mollusk, a whelk. [Prov. Eng.]
A waterspout. [Obs.]
imp. of Wring. Wrung. Chaucer.
Same as Whereto.
The quality or state of being whimsical; whimsicalness.

A plate the film of which retains its sensitiveness only whilewet. The film used in such plates is of collodion impregnated withbromides and iodides. Before exposure the plate is immersed in asolution of silver nitrate, and immediately after exposure it isdeveloped and fixed.
Hydraulic lime.
Mad; insane; possessed; rabid; furious; frantic. [Obs.][Written also wode.]Our hoste gan to swear as [if] he were wood. Chaucer.
Guardian; one set to watch over another. [Obs.] "Though thoupreyedest Argus . . . to be my wardcorps." Chaucer.

Any one of several species of shrews having fringed feet andcapable of swimming actively. The two common European species(Crossopus fodiens, and C. ciliatus) are the best known. The mostcommon American water shrew, or marsh shrew (Neosorex palustris), israrely seen, owing to its nocturnal habits.
Having a top, or head, shaped like the top of a covered wagon,or resembling in section or outline an inverted U, thus as, awagonheaded ceiling.
Either of two shrubs (Viburnum Lantana, and V. Opulus), socalled on account of their whitish branches.
Having no weight; imponderable; hence, light. Shak.
See Whang. [Obs. or Prov. Eng.]
Knowingly; with knowledge; by design.
A tribe of North American Indians who originally occupied theregion about Green Bay, Lake Michigan, but were driven back from thelake and nearly exterminated in 1640 by the IIlinnois.
An iron attachment on one end of a mast or boom, with a ring,through which another mast or boom is rigged out and secured; awythe. R. H. Dana, Jr.
Full of wrinkles; having a tendency to be wrinkled; corrugated;puckered. G. Eliot.His old wrinkly face grew quite blown out at last. Carlyle.
Same as Whitlow grass, under Whitlow.

Goods found of which the owner is not known; originally, suchgoods as a pursued thief threw away to prevent being apprehended,which belonged to the king unless the owner made pursuit of thefelon, took him, and brought him to justice. Blackstone.
A vessel for holding or conveying water, or for sprinklingwater on cloth, plants, etc.
Used to the way; broken. [R.]A horse that is not well wayed; he starts at every bird that fliesout the hedge. Selden.

A very large marine mammal (Trichecus rosmarus) of the Sealfamily, native of the Arctic Ocean. The male has long and powerfultusks descending from the upper jaw. It uses these in procuring foodand in fighting. It is hunted for its oil, ivory, and skin. It feedslargely on mollusks. Called also morse.
See 3d Windlass. [Obs.] Chaucer.
Knowingly. [Obs.] Spenser.
In a wailing manner.

Either one of two species of large, savage African wild hogs ofthe genus Phacochoerus. These animals have a pair of large, rough,fleshy tubercles behind the tusks and second pair behind the eyes.The tusks are large and strong, and both pairs curve upward. The bodyis scantily covered with bristles, but there is long dorsal mane. TheSouth African species (Phacochoerus Æthiopicus) is the best known.Called also vlacke vark. The second species (P. Æliani) is native ofthe coasts of the Red Sea.
Like, or coming near to, white. [Obs.]
Washed. Chaucer.
A young wolf. Carlyle.
Upon which; in consequence of which; after which.The townsmen mutinied and sent to Essex; whereupon he came thither.Clarendon.
Covered with an opaque white powder.
A waldgrave, or head forest keeper. See Waldgrave.The wildgrave winds his bugle horn. Sir W. Scott.
A running stream of water having a bed and banks; the easementone may have in the flowing of such a stream in its accustomedcourse. A water course may be sometimes dry. Angell. Burrill.
A list of passengers in a public vehicle, or of the baggage orgods transported by a common carrier on a land route. When the goodsare transported by water, the list is called a bill of lading.
A pot containing melted tin into which the plates are dipped tobe coated.
A kind of hanger or sword used as a knife at meals and as aweapon. [Scot. & Prov. Eng.]The chief acknowledged that he had corrected her with his whinger.Sir W. Scott.
Having a twisted distorted from.A writhen staff his step unstable guides. Fairfax.
To grow or become worse. De Quincey.Indifferent health, which seemed rather to worsen than improve.Carlyle.
To make war upon. [Obs.] Fairfax. "When a man warrayeth truth."Chaucer.
Same as Wolframite.
A labiate plant (Teucrium Scordium) found in marshy places inEurope.
The quality of being waterish.
Somewhat wild; rather wild. "A wildish destiny." Wordsworth.

The back of a woman's gown in which one or more very broadfolds are carried from the neck to the floor without being held in atthe waist, while the front and sides of the gown are shaped to theperson and have a belt or its equivalent.
A mill whose machinery is moved by water; -- distinguished froma windmill, and a steam mill.
A pustule; a whelk. Wiseman.
To snatch up; transport; -- chiefly used in the p. p. wrapt.Lo! where the stripling, wrapt in wonder, roves. Beattie.
Prevented by a flood from proceeding.

A bundle of fibers, or a loosely twisted or braided cord, tape,or tube, usually made of soft spun cotton threads, which by capillaryattraction draws up a steady supply of the oil in lamps, the meltedtallow or wax in candles, or other material used for illumination, insmall successive portions, to be burned.But true it is, that when the oil is spent The light goes out, andwick is thrown away. Spenser.
A remarkable meteorological phenomenon, of the nature of atornado or whirlwind, usually observed over the sea, but sometimesover the land.
An exclamation of grief. [Obs. or Prov. Eng. & Scot.]
Winter time. Tennyson.
Destitute of a wreath.
Of or pertaining to a web or webs; like a web; filled orcovered with webs.Bats on their webby wings in darkness move. Crabbe.
A young full trout during its second season. [Prov. Eng.]

A thermometer filled with water instead of mercury, forascertaining the precise temperature at which water attains itsmaximum density. This is about 39º Fahr., or 4º Centigrade; and fromthat point down to 32º Fahr., or 0º Centigrade, or the freezingpoint, it expands.
Contentious; quarrelsome. [Prov. Eng.] Halliwell.
To ret, or rot, in water, as flax; to water-rot.
A geld, or payment, for wood. Burrill.
One who warrants.
Xylan.
Any one of numerous species of elegant, usually white, marineshells of the genus Scalaria, especially Scalaria pretiosa, which wasformerly highly valued; -- called also staircase shell. See Scalaria.

Anything soever which; the thing or things of any kind; beingthis or that; of one nature or another; one thing or another;anything that may be; all that; the whole that; all particulars that;-- used both substantively and adjectively.Whatever fortune stays from his word. Shak.Whatever Earth, all-bearing mother, yields. Milton.Whatever be its intrinsic value. J. H. Newman.
Dried; shriveled; withered; shrunken; weazen; as, a wizened oldman.
The fruit or nut of any tree of the genus Juglans; also, thetree, and its timber. The seven or eight known species are allnatives of the north temperate zone.
People that labor.
To whirl round, or revolve, with a whizzing noise; to fly ormore quickly with a buzzing or whizzing sound; to whiz.The partridge bursts away on whirring wings. Beattie.
To roll; to spout; to boil up. [Obs.] Holland.
Having some or all of the tail quills terminated in a long,slender, pointed shaft, without a web or barbules.
Knowledge. [Obs.] "Withouten witing of any other wight."Chaucer.
Furnished with a leaflike appendage, as the fruit of the elmand the ash, or the stem in certain plants; alate.
A strong piece of plank used in applying wringbolts.
A black variety of the jaguar; -- called also tapir tiger.[Written also walla.]
Somewhat like whey; wheyey. J. Philips.-- Whey"ish*ness, n.
A timber bolted to a row of piles to secure them together andin position. Knight.
An inclined percussion table, usually with longitudinal groovesin its surface, agitated by side blows at right angles to the flow ofthe pulp; -- so called after the inventor.
To marry, as a man; to take a wife.Wherefore we pray you hastily to wive. Chaucer.
Being in good condition. [Obs. or Archaic]They also shall bring forth more fruit in their age, and shall be fatand well-liking. Bk. of Com. Prayer (Ps. xcii.).
A quantity; a goodly number. [Scot.] "A wheen other dogs." SirW. Scott.
An American freshwater bream, or sunfish (Chænobryttusgulosus); -- called also red-eyed bream.

In a wicked manner; in a manner, or with motives and designs,contrary to the divine law or the law of morality; viciously;corruptly; immorally.I have sinned, and I have done wickedly. 2 Sam. xxiv. 17.

Any one of numerous species of small Old World singing birdsbelonging to the family Sylviidæ, many of which are noted songsters.The bluethroat, blackcap, reed warbler (see under Reed), and sedgewarbler (see under Sedge) are well-known species.
See Leg, 7.
To wrestle with; to seek to throw down as in wrestling.
Woodbine. Dryden.A garland . . . of woodbind or hawthorn leaves. Chaucer.
Tear-filled. [R.] "Many an orphan's water-standing eye." Shak.
The quality or state of being wordy, or abounding with words;verboseness. Jeffrey.
One who, or that which, whitens; a bleacher; a blancher; awhitewasher.
To curse; to curse; to execrate; to condemn; also, to vex.[Obs.] [Spelled also warrie, warry, and wary.] "Whom I thus blame andwarye." Chaucer.
imp. & p. p. of Wind to twist, and Wind to sound by blowing.
imp. & p. p. of Wave.
Same as Wondrous.
Worn by the action of, or by exposure to, the weather.
One in a flight of steps which are curved in plan, so that eachtread is broader at one end than at the other; -- distinguished fromflyer.
Something that foreshows the weather. [Obs.] Derham.
Oppressed with weight; crushed; weighed down. [Obs.] Tusser.
See 2d Will.Pour out to all that wull. Spenser.
Any plant of the genus Myriophyllum, aquatic herbs with whorledleaves, the submersed ones pinnately parted into capillary divisions.
Becoming a woman; feminine; as, womanly behavior. Arbuthnot.A blushing, womanly discovering grace. Donne.
Full of wealth; wealthy; prosperous. [R.] Sir T. More.-- Wealth"ful*ly, adv. [R.]

Any one of numerous species of beetles belonging to Gyrinus andallied genera. The body is firm, oval or boatlike in form, andusually dark colored with a bronzelike luster. These beetles livemostly on the surface of water, and move about with great celerity ina gyrating, or circular, manner, but they are also able to dive andswim rapidly. The larva is aquatic. Called also weaver, whirlwig, andwhirlwig beetle.
See Cartbote. See also the Note under Bote.

A kind of white and fine bread or cake; -- called also wastelbread, and wastel cake. [Obs.]Roasted flesh or milk and wasted bread. Chaucer.The simnel bread and wastel cakes, which were only used at the tablesof the highest nobility. Sir W. Scott.
A piece of plank two yard Bailey.
A trade market in the woolen districts. [Eng.]

a. & n. from Wander, v. Wandering albatross (Zoöl.), the greatwhite albatross. See Illust. of Albatross.-- Wandering cell (Physiol.), an animal cell which possesses thepower of spontaneous movement, as one of the white corpuscles of theblood.-- Wandering Jew (Bot.), any one of several creeping species ofTradescantia, which have alternate, pointed leaves, and a soft,herbaceous stem which roots freely at the joints. They are commonlycultivated in hanging baskets, window boxes, etc.-- Wandering kidney (Med.), a morbid condition in which one kidney,or, rarely, both kidneys, can be moved in certain directions; --called also floating kidney, movable kidney.-- Wandering liver (Med.), a morbid condition of the liver, similarto wandering kidney.-- Wandering mouse (Zoöl.), the whitefooted, or deer, mouse. SeeIllust. of Mouse.-- Wandering spider (Zoöl.), any one of a tribe of spiders thatwander about in search of their prey.
To wallow. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One who makes wagons.
A vinelike plant (Vitis Caribæa) growing in parched districtsin the West Indies, and containing a great amount of sap which issometimes used for quenching thirst.
To fill with whimseys, or whims; to make fantastic; to craze.[R.]To have a man's brain whimsied with his wealth. J. Fletcher.
Through which. [R.] "Wherethrough that I may know." Chaucer.Windows . . . wherethrough the sun Delights to peep, to gaze thereinon thee. Shak.
One who forms webs; a weaver; a webster. [Obs.]
Whencesoever. [R.]
The wheatear. [Prov. Eng.]

The price of a man's head; a compensation paid of a man killed,partly to the king for the loss of a subject, partly to the lord of avassal, and partly to the next of kin. It was paid by the murderer.[Written also weregeld, weregelt, etc.] Blackstone.
A light vehicle for conveying small loads. It has two handlesand one wheel, and is rolled by a single person.
The keeper of a warren.
An incessant motion of a horse's head, neck, and body, fromside to side, fancied to resemble the motion of a hand weaver inthrowing the shuttle. Youatt.
Hubbub. [Obs.] Beau. & Fl.
The state or condition of being well; welfare; happiness;prosperity; as, virtue is essential to the well-being of men or ofsociety.
Anger; madness; insanity; rage. [Obs.] Spenser.Woodness laughing in his rage. Chaucer.
War. [Obs.] Chaucer.

, The second person singular, indicative and subjunctive moods,imperfect tense, of the verb be. It is formed from were, with theending -t, after the analogy of wast. Now used only in solemn orpoetic style.
Having yellow or red for a basis, or in their composition; --said of colors, and opposed to cold which is of blue and itscompounds.
See Canker, n., 1.
One of several pivoted pieces forming the throat of anadjustable die used in drawing wire, lead pipe, etc. Knight.
To serve the purpose of a watchman by floating properly in itsplace; -- said of a buoy. To watch over, to be cautiously observantof; to inspect, superintend, and guard.
To strike; to beat; to give a heavy or resounding blow to; tothrash; to make with whacks. [Colloq.]Rodsmen were whackingtheir way through willow brakes. G. W. Cable.
Any one of several species of Nuphar; the yellow frog lily; --so called from the shape of the seed vessel. See Nuphar, and cf.Candock. Dr. Prior.
See Whelked.
One who wakens.
Native lead molybdate occurring in tetragonal crystals, usuallytabular, and of a bright orange-yellow to red, gray, or brown color;-- also called yellow lead ore.
A fabric designed for waistcoats; esp., one in which there is apattern, differently colored yarns being used.
A woodman; especially, one who lives in the forest.
Full of worth; worthy; deserving. Marston.
Money paid for transportation of goods, etc., by water. [Eng.]
Whisperingly. [R.]
pl. of Woman.
Whither. [Obs.] Chaucer.
A plant of any kind.
See Withe.
Same as 1st Willow, 2.
An Australian crested insessorial bird (Sphenostoma cristatum)having a wedge-shaped bill. Its color is dull brown, like the earthof the plains where it lives.
The yaffle. [Written also woodwale, and woodwele.]
Alas! [Obs.]Then welaway, for she undone was clean. Wyatt.

Originally, the title of a military commander in variousSlavonic countries; afterwards applied to governors of towns orprovinces. It was assumed for a time by the rulers of Moldavia andWallachia, who were afterwards called hospodars, and has also beengiven to some inferior Turkish officers. [Written also vaivode,voivode, waiwode, and woiwode.]
A more or less subtle playing upon the meaning of words.
The harvest mite; -- so called from the wheals, caused by itsbite.
A sprite, or spirit, imagined as inhabiting the water. J. R.Drake.
A variety of epidote, of a reddish color, found in Scotland.
A person who has little wit or understanding; a pretender towit or smartness.A beau and witing perished in the forming. Pope.Ye newspaper witlings! ye pert scribbling folks! Goldsmith.
A liquor made from the pulp of crab apples after the verjuiceis expressed; -- sometimes called crab wherry. [Prov. Eng.]Halliwell.
In a witty manner; wisely; ingeniously; artfully; with it; witha delicate turn or phrase, or with an ingenious association of ideas.Who his own harm so wittily contrives. Dryden.
See under Assembly.
A flock of swans.
One who wields or employs; a manager; a controller.A wielder of the great arm of the war. Milton.
A very acrid herb (Ranunculus sceleratus) growing in ditchesand wet places; -- called also cursed crowfoot.
One who welds, or unites pieces of iron, etc., by welding.
Talk; discourse; speech; language.Why should calamity be full of words Shak.Be thy words severe; Sharp as he merits, but the sword forbear.Dryden.
Very angry. [Colloq.]
p. p. of Wear. Worn land, land that has become exhausted bytillage, or which for any reason has lost its fertility.
The hawthorn.
A species of steel imported from the East Indies, valued formaking edge tools; Indian steel. It has in combination a minuteportion of alumina and silica.
Whatever person; any person who; be or she who; any one who;as, he shall be punished, whoever he may be. "Whoever envies orrepines." Milton. "Whoever the king favors." Shak.
Whip handle; whipstock.
To refuse. [Obs.]He is too great a niggard that will wern A man to light a candle athis lantern. Chaucer.
A tribe of Indians native of the region between the Arkansasand Red rivers. They are related to the Pawnees. See Pawnees.
Anemophilous; fertilized by pollen borne by the wind.
The quality or state of having a place; ubiety; situation;position. [R.]A point hath no dimensions, but only a whereness, and is next tonothing. Grew.

A follower of Abdel Wahab (b. 1691; d. 1787), a reformer ofMohammedanism. His doctrines prevail particularly among the Bedouins,and the sect, though checked in its influence, extends to most partsof Arabia, and also into India. [Written also Wahaby.]
Same as Inch of water, under Water.
To pass the winter; to hibernate; as, to winter in Florida.Because the haven was not commodious to winter in, the more partadvised to depart thence. Acts xxvii. 12.
Of or pertaining to Whigs; partaking of, or characterized by,the principles of Whigs.

Any of several plants bearing thorns or stiff hookedappendages, which catch and tear the clothing, as:(a) The greenbrier.(b) Any of various species of hawthorn.(c) In South Africa, one of numerous acacias and mimosas.(d) The grapple plant.(e) The prickly ash.
To see the execution of, as an instrument, and subscribe it forthe purpose of establishing its authenticity; as, to witness a bondor a deed.
Whatsoever person; any person whatever that; whoever.Whosoever will, let him take . . . freely. Rev. xxii. 17.
See Welfare. [Obs.]

To salute with kindness, as a newcomer; to receive andentertain hospitably and cheerfully; as, to welcome a visitor; towelcome a new idea. "I welcome you to land." Addison.Thus we salute thee with our early song, And welcome thee, and wishthee long. Milton.
See Wormil.
In a westward direction.
Capable of, or suitable for, being written down.
Skillful in forecasting the changes of the weather. Hakluyt.
Wearied by traveling.
Having the form of a wedge; cuneiform. Wedge-formed characters.See Arrow-headed characters, under Arrowheaded.
A seaman, usually a green hand or a broken-down man, stationedin the waist of a vessel of war. R. H. Dana, Jr.
A member of the Washingtonian Society.
A privy; especially, a privy furnished with a contrivance forintroducing a stream of water to cleanse it.

Wherewith. "Wherewithal shall we be clothed" Matt. vi. 31.Wherewithal shall a young man cleanse his way Ps. cxix. 9.[The builders of Babel], still with vain design, New Babels, had theywherewithal, would build. Milton.
A whisket, or basket. [Prov. Eng.] Ainsworth.
Free from wound or hurt; exempt from being wounded;invulnerable. "Knights whose woundless armor rusts." Spenser.[Slander] may miss our name, And hit the woundless air. Shak.
Any aquatic pulmonate gastropod belonging to Planorbis, Limnæa,and allied genera; a pond snail.
A European squill (Scilla nonscripta) having a scape bearing araceme of drooping blue, purple, white, or sometimes pink, bell-shaped flowers.
Skillful in finding the way; well acquainted with the way orroute; wise from having traveled.
One who courts widows, seeking to marry one with a fortune.Addison.
Week. [Obs.] Chaucer.
One destitute of wit or sense; a blockhead; a fool. [Obs.]Shak.

A rare alkaloid found in the bark of an East Indianapocynaceous tree (Wrightia antidysenterica), and extracted as abitter white crystalline substance. It was formerly used as a remedyfor diarrhoea. Called also conessine, and neriine.

The system made up of a force and a couple of forces in a planeperpendicular to that force. Any number of forces acting at anypoints upon a rigid body may be compounded so as to be equivalent toa wrench. Carriage wrench, a wrench adapted for removing ortightening the nuts that confine the wheels on the axles, or forturning the other nuts or bolts of a carriage or wagon.-- Monkey wrench. See under Monkey.-- Wrench hammer, a wrench with the end shaped so as to admit ofbeing used as a hammer.

Any one of several species of finchlike birds belonging to thegenus Vidua, native of Asia and Africa. In the breeding season themale has very long, drooping tail feathers. Called also vida finch,whidah finch, whydah bird, whydah finch, widow bird, and widow finch.
The burning bush; -- said to be called after a quack medicinemade from it.

To move nimbly; to start or turn suddenly and do something; towhisk; as, he whipped around the corner.With speed from thence he whipped. Sackville.Two friends, traveling, met a bear upon the way; the one whips up atree, and the other throws himself flat upon the ground. L'Estrange.
The water chestnut.

The obligation by which a person, conveying a subject or aright, is bound to uphold that subject or right against every claim,challenge, or burden arising from circumstances prior to theconveyance; warranty. [Written also warrandise.] Craig.
